Modded Game:
TL DR: With mods like Thrawn's revenge, Age of the rebellion, Fall of the republic, etc. This game is a must play!!!

The mods I mentioned above are complete overhauls which give you
improved graphics, new factions, campaigns, storys, eras(like the clone wars) maps, planets, ships, heroes, ground forces, mechanics and add a new time system. The Economy system also gets improved with some mods (Thrawn's revenge for example)

There's one mod called Empire at War: Remastered that's dedicated to lift up the games graphics to today's standard's. And it does that amazingly well!

And the best is: The devs love what the modding community does with the game and they still update the game to give the mod devs more possibilities to change the game.

Great game but the expansion is kind of a mess. I sunk hundreds of hours into it throughout out junior high and high school and it was my only PC game for a long time after I bought the Gold Pack from Walmart when PC games didn't all need Steam or whatever the other ones are.

The base game is pretty well balanced and every unit has its place and time as you progress through the tech tree. No unit ever feels OP and newer ones replace old ones at a fair pace. 
The two factions are designed to play differently and uniquely with minimal extra mechanics. The AI does seem to cheat a little as it often seems to have a suspicious amount of money but that's probably an attempt to make up how predictable the AI is. Micromanaging units will often counteract the massive fleets of hundreds of Rebel ships with ease but it will take time to learn how to properly use your units.

The space battles are definitely better than the land battles. Land battles aren't bad but the terrain and unit pathing can cause units to get stuck or try to take unreasonably long routes to a point on the map or even get stuck driving back and forth in the same spot.

The expansion on the other hand adds a third faction that has all their units and heroes available from the start, one of which can destroy the Death Star from the galactic map out of nowhere with no warning. Some units like Vader's TIE fighter are bugged and locked to the wrong plane in skirmish battles making it impossible for him to dogfight enemy fighters and in Galactic Conquest he is a Super Stardestroyer that sometimes takes up a third of the map and can solo the average sized AI fleets almost every time even on higher difficulties.

The Consortium is also extremely annoying to play against as they cover the map in a fart gas that lets them blow up your bases with money and reveals your fleets to them as well as crippling your defenses. Since the AI seems to have an excessive amount of money an AI Consortium will quickly cover half the map in an ugly green color and will often blow up base buildings on planets that aren't even close to them or important. It can often be predicted what planets they will sabotage as the all three AI have fixation on certain planets like Eriadu for no apparent reason.

The expansion adds lots of units that are useless like 2 out of the 3 Darktroopers or the Consortium's anti-air missile launcher that can't kill aircraft, bugged like Vader and Luke as starfighters, or wildly overpowered like the B-Wing and Skipray Blastboat. The expansion is also a step down from the base game visually as parts of buildings and space stations that were previously animated are no longer and some textures look off somehow.

The modding scene is generally pretty impressive but also full of large scale projects that were too big and have long been dropped.

[b][i][u]"It's an older game, sir, but it checks out."[/u][/i][/b]

A long time ago, back when Steam wasn't a thing, I remember playing [i]Star Wars: Galactic Battlegrounds[/i] and the [i]Clone Campaigns[/i] expansion. It's basically [i]Age of Empires[/i] with a [i]Star Wars[/i] skin. However, it was missing one crucial element:

[i]"Where are the massive space battles? And no, battles on the surface of 'asteroids' do not count."[/i]

So when I saw first-look promotional screenshots of [i]Star Wars: Empire at War[/i] and how they included space battles with every size of ship imaginable from nimble X-Wings to the intimidating Imperial Star Destroyers, I knew I had to play it. It helps that Petroglyph, the developers, already had experience with real-time strategy games before...under the former Westwood Studios, before they moved out and started their new studio after the Electronic Arts acquisition.

Anyway, I convinced a local Internet gaming cafe to install the game on their PCs a month or so after release, and I spent hours upon hours playing both Imperial and Rebel campaigns. However, that Internet gaming cafe would close its doors around 2007 before I got the chance to play the expansion, [i]Forces of Corruption[/i]. It would take nearly 12 years, the introduction of Steam, getting and upgrading a decent 2010s PC, and getting the game on sale before I could finally experience the exploits of Tyber Zann and his Consortium. (Tyber Zann? More like Tyber Chad, am I right?)

After seeing Disney's acquisition of the [i]Star Wars[/i] franchise and this game (along with [i]Republic Commando[/i] and many other [i]Expanded Universe[/i] series) being thrown into the [i]Star Wars: Legends[/i] bin, and Electronic Arts making a pathetically paltry amount of feature-incomplete and deliberately grindy live-service [i]Star Wars[/i] games (and the [i]Souls[/i]-like [i]Star Wars: Jedi[/i] series), I'm still glad that I have [i]Empire at War[/i] as an option. And the modding community has done a great deal to keep this game aging like a well-blended Scotch whisky.

[b][i][u]Star Wars Empire at War: Gold Pack (Empire at War + Forces of Corruption) - The Good, Bad and Ugly[/u][/i][/b]

[b]The Good:[/b]
[list]
[*] Fulfills the classic strategy geek fantasy of commanding squadrons of Rebel X-Wings + Y-Wings or a fleet of Imperial Star Destroyers in space battles. (Or blowing planets up with the Galactic Empire's Death Stars. Or becoming rich and powerful through crime with the Zann Consortium.) Though come for the ISD spam, stay to learn proper combined arms/combined fleet tactics (and screw the Tarkin Doctrine).
[*] Three engaging (for its time) single-player story campaigns (Rebel Alliance, Galactic Empire, and the expansion's Zann Consortium) that introduce the player to the basic gameplay premise as well as each faction's playstyle and units. 
[*] A Galactic Conquest mode where the only objectives are the ones you set (plus what new planets are revealed) and the ultimate goal of ruling/liberating/corrupting the galaxy, with challenges like the "Single-planet start".
[*] The re-enabled multiplayer, many years after the old GameSpy servers shut down.
[*] A nice throwback to the old [i]Star Wars Expanded Universe[/i] (a.k.a.: [i]Legends[/i]) continuity with references galore, back when there's still fun to be had in new [i]Star Wars[/i] games and less "live-service" elements (if not none).
[*] Petroglyph's dedication to keeping the game updated [b][i]17 years[/i][/b] after release (recently getting a 64-bit update in November of 2023). On a similar note...
[*] Their support for the modding community.
[*] And of course, the aforementioned modding community that extends the game's longevity beyond its 2006(!) vintage. From mods that keep the feel of the old vanilla game yet add new units ([i]Absolute Corruption Mod[/i]) and dive into other time periods of [i]Star Wars[/i] like the Clone Wars ([i]Republic at War[/i]), to mods that ramp up the challenge like a [i]Souls[/i] game ([i]Awakening of the Rebellion[/i]), to more ambitious total expansion mods (Empire at War Expanded's [i]Thrawn's Revenge[/i], [i]Fall of the Republic[/i], and the upcoming [i]Revan's Revenge[/i]) that basically adds planetary management/political influence mechanics akin to what you'd usually see in 4X games like the [i]Total War[/i] series, to a very ambitious remake ([i]Empire at War Remake[/i]) that vastly improves the graphics from 2006 and updates it for the 2020s (sadly not for Potato PCs).
[/list]

[b]The Bad and Ugly:[/b]
[list]
[*] Considering this is an older RTS game, there are times where unit pathfinding can be a problem. Even with your best RTS micromanagement skills, the unit pathfinding sometimes goes all over the place, except the spot where you want the unit(s) to be. (Also exposes how clumsy and lumbering the AT-AT platform is, even if its turbolasers shred most ground units and structures.)
[*] Arbitrary unit/population cap--space battles. Thank goodness for mods that increase the popcap even a little to replicate the epic, large-scale space battles seen in the Original and Prequel Trilogies plus the [i]Expanded Universe[/i].
[*] Arbitrary unit/population cap--land battles. And in vanilla, you have to push towards other landing zones with sometimes limited forces to increase your popcap, though you'll hit the unit limit pretty quickly. Defending is much easier if you have multiple unit-producing structures that spit out free garrison units. But if you don't have enough or only have three building slots on the planet and an anemic actual garrison stationed there, you're screwed.
[*] Conquering a small portion of a planet to establish planetary control kinda breaks immersion, but understandable. It keeps the ground battles much shorter and (relatively) less grindy than it already is.
[*] Somewhat basic selection of units that run on tactical rock-paper-scissors, both on land and in space (some of the units being Petroglyph homebrews). Again, game mods add new units referenced in either the [i]Expanded Universe[/i] works or (part of) the new Disney canon.
[*] Somewhat limited variety of planets/land maps, though that's mostly because of the rather limited assets of the land map editor. Some improvements on the land map editor and additional assets (buildings/doodads) referencing other places in the galaxy (both from Disney Canon and old [i]Expanded Universe[/i]) will go a long way keeping this game enjoyable.
[*] "Space" is mainly 2-D space, albeit with different layers/depths for capital ships, cruisers, frigates, missile cruisers, anti-fighter corvettes and fighters/bombers. (I know, not every RTS with a space combat element can be like [i]Homeworld[/i].)
[*] Somewhat dated graphics, though mods like the aforementioned [i]Empire at War Remake[/i] give it a much-needed makeover.
[/list]

[b][i]The Verdict/TL;DR:[/i][/b]
- [i]Empire at War[/i]'s graphics may not hold up as well today as it did back in the simpler times of 2006, but this game's passionate and dedicated modding community (with the tacit support of Petroglyph) has kept it alive and kicking for the past 17 years (and counting). At a time when newer [i]Star Wars[/i] games are usually live-service ("modern" [i]Battlefront[/i]) or mobile dreck with predatory microtransactions, and single-player experiences are rare (the [i]Souls[/i]-like [i]Star Wars: Jedi[/i] series), older [i]Star Wars[/i] games like [i]Empire at War[/i], [i]Republic Commando[/i], the classic [i]Battlefront[/i] games and even the old [i]Galactic Battlegrounds[/i] (to name a few) become nostalgic priceless treasures--or oases in the midst of a rapidly expanding desert.

[b][i]3.5/5 stars[/i][/b] vanilla; [b][i]4/5 stars[/i][/b] with mods.

I used to have this game on disc and thoroughly enjoyed playing it when it was new and I was much younger! Empire At War is exactly what I want from a Star Wars game: unit variation, charm, strategy, and epic space battles with amazing ships. Let's be honest, we play for the space battles. The campaign, galactic conquest, and multiplayer are all top notch. Galactic conquest and multiplayer, in particular, are my choice. 

Having EAW available on Steam is great. I must give a shout-out to Petroglyph for having recently patching the game to improve multiplayer stability. THANK YOU, PETROGLYPH!  Multiplayer is now enjoyable and provides a great time with friends either against each other or teaming up against the computer AI.
 
The modding community has continually added unique assortments over the years. I love playing the base game, but some of the mods take it to a whole other level. Massive selection of fleet units to build, more specialized units, and heavy star destroyers, super star destroyers! What's not to love about this? Thank you to the modding community for expanding the game to include so much more. 

If you enjoy Star Wars and like RTS games, then please do yourself a favor and give it a purchase and review. Show your support for a game genre that doesn't get too much support anymore. There are still many of us out there who prefer games like this over a typical FPS.

This game was probably beyond amazing back in its day. However, in 2024 it has aged immensely when compared to other RTS/Strategy-type games. After 10+ hours of really trying to like this game, I just can't do it and have lost all desire to continue. 

My biggest gripe is probably the lack of base building actually in-game, as opposed to being done on the star map. This is exacerbated by the constant 'Battle Commencing' pop-up that never ends, as the opposing faction invades your planets space and then planet surface. 

You literally spend hours building ships and troops to counter-act the endless tug-of-war match that is taking place as you fight for planets. I got to a point where I was still losing plants with ~100 supply worth of space ships and ~100 supply worth of ground troops (my supply count was around 230 combined) ... and still losing space battles and/or planets... only to have to rebuild and then do it all over again... and then again. 

Go ahead and throw down the learn to play, skill issues, etc. That's fine. Not going to dedicate my free time to mastering a game that is nearly 20 years old. I was looking for a causal experience and some light-hearted Star Wars RTS. It's kinda here... but the overall game style mechanics of this game is just simply not fun to me. 

Maybe mods offer a lot of new things, but I don't even need to bother with them because I already know it is just all more of the same, if not even harder difficulty from what I've read. 

I play games in my free time to relax and unwind. Not to be stressed or feel like I have a list of chores. 

If anything that I've written above resonates, I do not recommend. Not even on sale, but certainly not for a $19.99 at full price.

Empire At War (base game): I recommend waiting for this game to go on sale. 20 bucks is a bit much for a repetitive grind the base game can be. I had some fun with the base game especially learning how to use units effectively. Space battles become very similar and repetitive. The AI doesn't know how to deal with bombing runs in combination with the sensor ping ability making ground battle very easy for Rebels. The story is a simple retelling of events that lead to Star Wars: A New Hope from both the Rebel and Empire side that stay true to legends continuity pretty well.

Forces of Corruption: It's DLC expansion Forces of Corruption is a more well-rounded than base game. It adds a lot of added complexity to the gameplay. It adds a new Campaign for a new faction the Zann Consortium plus new units and heroes to existing factions. I enjoyed this DLC very much. The AI is more aggressive compared to the base game, which address many issue I had with the base game's AI. The story gets very fan fic despite this I did enjoy the references to classic Legends content: Dark Forces, The Thrawn trilogy, Shadow of the Empire, Therefore I Am, and Tie Fighter (video game). Although, it is very silly that Tyber Zann is able to outsmart Jabba, Xizor, Vader, and Thrawn. The DLC story ends on a cliffhanger that is never resolved. 

Issues/fixes: The final level on Kaut for Forces of Corruption is prone to crashes. so save often. Also, the DLC can only be launch in the steam launcher, not the shortcut.

I recommend picking it up for 10 bucks or less on steam. The base game is good but flawed and it's DLC is great.

I recently had the absolute pleasure of immersing myself in the Star Wars universe through the incredible gaming experience offered by Star Wars: Empire at War Gold Pack. As a longtime fan of both the Star Wars franchise and real-time strategy games, this title exceeded all my expectations and delivered an unforgettable journey across the galaxy.

From the moment I launched the game, I was captivated by the stunning graphics and attention to detail. The visual representation of iconic Star Wars planets, starships, and ground units is nothing short of breathtaking. The developers truly went above and beyond to recreate the essence of the Star Wars universe, and it felt like I was commanding my own fleet in the midst of epic space battles or leading ground forces to conquer planets.

The Gold Pack's inclusion of both the base game and the Forces of Corruption expansion is a stroke of genius. It adds a whole new layer to the gameplay, introducing the criminal underworld and allowing players to experience the Star Wars saga from a different perspective. The diversity of factions, units, and strategies available kept me engaged and excited throughout my entire playthrough.

The strategic depth of Empire at War is commendable. Managing resources, constructing fleets, and strategically deploying forces are all crucial aspects of the game that require thoughtful planning. The balance between space and ground battles is exceptionally well-executed, ensuring that each aspect contributes to the overall immersive experience.

One of the standout features is the galactic conquest mode, where players can wage epic campaigns for control of the galaxy. This mode provides a sandbox-like experience, allowing for a high level of replayability as players can experiment with different strategies and explore alternate storylines. It truly feels like you're shaping the fate of the Star Wars galaxy with every decision you make.

The sound design deserves special mention, as it perfectly complements the visuals to create an authentic Star Wars atmosphere. The iconic music, voiceovers, and sound effects transport players into the heart of the action, enhancing the overall sense of immersion.

In conclusion, Star Wars: Empire at War Gold Pack is a must-have for any fan of the Star Wars franchise or strategy gaming enthusiast. It successfully marries the beloved Star Wars universe with engaging gameplay, resulting in a gaming experience that is nothing short of legendary. May the Force be with anyone who embarks on this extraordinary journey!

Released in 2006, this game brought real time strategy the Star Wars universe, again. Star Wars: Rebellion walked so that this game could run. The game aged well and is like a fine vintage wine, if that's your thing. Even though this title was released in 2006, the developers keep coming back once a year to tune up the release to allow for the massive modding community to have more tools to continue to create wonderful things.

Empire at War is kept alive to this day by talented mod developers that create "total conversion" mods that completely overhaul how the game is played and how the game looks. Workshop integration was the best thing to have happened to Empire at War, hands down. 

Do you like the Old Republic era? There's a mod for that. Do you like the Post Endor era? There's a mod. What about the Clone Wars, you say? There's a mod for that.

Highly recommend that you pick this up if you love Star Wars, space battles, mods and empire building. 

I am excited for what the developers and mod devs plan to tweak and create next.

Performance works far better, I have less tinkering to maximise 1-2 of my CPU cores to get this to run better now. I look forward to see if they release a sequel. Empire at War is a pretty great game for what it is. The space combat is pretty easy to pick up and, more importantly, feels very Star Wars. It's an old game but there is still an active modding community that keeps things pretty fresh. The developers also support this game even to this day with very recent patches bringing the aging game into 64 bit and fixing a long-standing save game bug. Given the current trend of remaking classic games, I wouldn't be surprised if this was an attempt to show interest in doing so and it would totally deserve it. 

Now it isn't without flaws, to be clear. The land combat is very forgettable and obnoxious at times, despite the stellar space combat. The galaxy management in galactic conquest is pretty shallow, though it generally does what it needs to in my opinion and would probably not benefit from too much more tacked on. Lastly, the main story is great but the expansion's story is pretty comical for what it is.

This is probably one of the best RTS games of all time. Let alone the best Star Wars RTS. Yes it's old. Yes the graphics are dated now. But the gameplay is still incredibly fun, and there is still a highly dedicated modding community supporting this game. 

Not to mention the devs still releasing the occasional fix updates despite THE GAME RELEASING 18 YEARS AGO.

This game is pretty fun, but I would not recommend getting this game if you want to play it with your friends. The game is very unbalanced towards the rebels, and there are only two factions, so playing with more than two players is not interesting because the additional players just leech off of one of the already existing factions. As far as gameplay goes, it takes some getting used to but makes sense once you understand it. Some parts are still a bit janky, though, specifically controlling everything is space battles, and the mechanics of some of the heroes. There is some mod/workshop support for this game, but I have not found any mods that are particularly helpful or fun. If you really like RTS games though, you will probably still like it well enough.

What can't be said about this? Empire at War is one of the greatest Star Wars games created in my eyes, if you love RTS games and want to experience being in charge of the rebellion after episode three or controlling the empire during the original trilogy this is the perfect game for it. The standard edition is a little buggy and hasn't aged as well as it should but the forces of corruption expansion is INCREDIBLE.

I basically grew up with this game before discovering it on steam, the modding community is INSANE stretching from adding the ENTIRE CLONE WARS to even adding after endor death star explosion content. I enjoy basic RTS games yet feel overwhelmed sometimes by games such as supreme commander or age of empires, this game feels like a perfect introduction to the genre and lets you play at your own pace. The community for a game this old is steady strong and not backing down.

The base game alone on FOC has you play as a pirate lord slowly corrupting the galaxy as well as lets you simulate endless scenarios in skrimish and conquest battles.

If you install a mod that removes the unit cap you can literally have large scale hundreds/thousands unit battles and live your Star Wars fantasy.

Best part is, the multiplayer still has active players. I would 100% recommend this game to any and all Star Wars fans.
Love RTS games? Love Star Wars? Play this game. It's almost 20 but still holds up!

This could have been a great game but it's completely disbalanced.

In the first mission you have to let CP30 and R2D2 hack somewhere which takes 2 minutes. In the meanwhile you're attacked by ~10 AT-AT (those big machines). 

The best that you can create are "light tanks" which are extremely underwhelming. It takes like 30 hits from a tank to kill a single soldier! Imagine how useless these vehicles are! While the AT-AT can do some serious damage to your tanks and soldiers.

Your tanks can be taken out in a single shot by the enemy's anti-vehicle turret.

I like this game. Space combat remains one of the most underutilized parts of Star Wars, despite being present in a large amount of the games and movies. To this scale, is what I mean. A Venator, of which we see a maximum of around 6 in the space focused episodes of TCW, are mere fractions of a fleet here. The chaos and balance of space combat, the coordinated sound of Turbolasers and ordinance, and everything falling into place is what keeps me playing this game. Most of my time has been modded playthroughs, as the community has found what works and expands on it to the best of their abilities. Say what you will about Star Wars, I surely have, but it's (formerly, via Legends) large scope attracts some extremely passionate minds. To the many people who have worked on this game for the past many years, weaving a collection of mechanics into place to create some of the most satisfying combat I've seen in my life, some of the largest scale I've seen (seriously, an SSD doesn't take up the whole screen, fighters are micro sized in most mods), as well as gotten me into the expansive works of SW Legends, thanks.

Star Wars: Empire at War is indeed a classic gem, especially given its age. The base game alone offers a fantastic experience, but the real magic happens when you delve into the world of mods. Titles like Thrawn's Revenge, Empire at War Expanded, and Remake Awakening of the Rebellion inject new life and possibilities into the game, providing an expansive and diverse range of content for players to explore.

However, it's worth noting that, despite the game's brilliance, there are performance issues, and lag can be a persistent concern across different settings. Despite these technical hiccups, the game's overall appeal and the added depth through mods make it a beloved choice among Star Wars and strategy game enthusiasts.

The community's dedication to enhancing the game through mods is a testament to its enduring popularity. Many fans share sentiment and hope for the development of additional Star Wars: Empire at War games in the future, capitalizing on the success and fond memories created by this iconic title. Here's to hoping the galaxy far, far away continues to expand in the gaming universe!

okay so listen, this game is great for people who like managing colonies but without all the fluff of micromanaging each colony. You get me? You only worry about influence of the government and the income of the planet, you automatically assume the planet's people are okay. 

Secondly, the game is perfect in space and ground combat as the big variety of ships allows for great space combat and creativity. Additionally, the controls are not hard to understand at all, its great how easy it was to remember. 

Lastly, the amount of mods the game has is just stunning. It really adds a bigger ground for opportunities within the experience.

every few months, one gets an itch. and there are very few if any games like this. 
Sure, there are better 4x games, sure there are better RTS games. But for a game whose sandbox is its own campaign, combing both grand and real time strategy, its a wonder why noone has tried something similar.

In the various overhaul mods, dont fool yourself. The AI is mean, and it will out produce and hit you from all fronts. You need to be astute in your decision making, conservative with your forces for they are hard to replace or can be lost entirely like hero units in some mods. Do you focus on early aggression, before your enemy has time to dig in, but with the limited forces at your disposal? Do you play defensive, trying to hold on all fronts? Do you play economic, giving nonessential worlds whilst taking valuable ones, whilst simultaneously investing in your economy and hanging on for dear life until its up and running?

All are viable, all can be done. But its how you choose.

History lesson:



A long long time ago in this very galaxy LucasArts made a game called "Star Wars: Rebellion". It was a RTS game that was released under Windows 95. While this game was VERY fun, it did have a lot of flaws built into it. (one example would be an overuse of windows). The fans liked the game anyways, and demanded Rebellion 2. LucasArts developed Star Wars: Empire at War (originally called Rebellion 2) 



Review:



This game is a must have for any Star Wars fan, but in reality, it is not the game that Petroglyph wanted to make. Unfortunately, LucasArts tended to be fairly impatient with the release of the games and would rush games to the stores before they were even really ready. While a lot of the errors can be seen if you know what to look for, and the AI will cheat (the higher the difficulty, the more the AI will cheat. The only real way it gets "more difficult" is by having things there is no way it should have. The tactics the computer uses aginst you is always the same), it is still a very fun game. I have spent many a hour playing this game. The graphics are good, the sound is what you would expect from a Star Wars game, and the voice acting is very good.

Edit: The devs recently published an update. This shows just how much life this game still has.
Great mods, still getting the rare update, solid if relatively barebones merchanics. Absolute recommend if you like star wars and RTS games.

The Empire at War Gold pack is one of the best Star Wars games ever, without a doubt being the best Star Wars strategy game. The two games mix ground and space combat layers to really give you the Star Wars universe feel. Get stuck in as the Rebel Alliance or align with the Empire, however maybe the underworld is more your thing so work with the Zann Consortium to take the galaxy. Three unique factions with their own play-style.

 The 2 games have a nice Campaign to familiarize players with the tactical and strategic layers of the game. A galactic conquest mode to allow players to take the galaxy by force as their chosen faction and a skirmish mode for a more focused experience.

 This is an older game that is well worth it to any Star Wars fan or those who love strategic games; Even being an older game the developers have been updating this game many years after its release, fixing bugs and even recently upgrading the game to a 64 bit program. 

 If that was not enough this experience has an active and expansive Modding scene with many different ways to extend the life of base game and breath new life into the game-play.

 I wholeheartedly recommend the Empire at War Gold Pack.

Empire at War (Forces of Corruption, not original base game) is one of the best games I've ever played in my life. Base game is a little buggy with enemy heroes spawning in space above enemy planets even if you have forces occupying the space as well, but it's a simple fix, with the movement of a unit to another space slot to start a battle and clear the confusion. There are a few issues, the standard broken units, bugs, and occasional AI-cheating shenanigans, there's not much else. The Rebels are a little OP with their stealing of technology and ability to raid with every single unit as long as you don't have more than 3-6 units per stack, the Empire snowballs pretty quickly with their later tech giving a lot of broken and OP units and heroes, and the Consortium is a hot mess to play against when fighting their corruption (like it's NON STOP CORRUPTION no matter what you do, no matter how many defilers you neutralize or how much corruption you remove), but I still enjoy playing it because it's a very unique game, and while yes some games seem to have the same style, no modern game has replicated an experience like this for Star Wars (Stellaris is close, but you don't play as the Empire or Rebels unless you use a mod).

In addition to what I have previously said, I would like to bring to attention just a small handful of the great mods that this game has that completely change the base game as a whole. (These are in random order, this is not my personal ranking or preference, all are equally awesome in their own rights)


Awakening of the Rebellion (AoTR): Created by the Steiner Modding Group (SMG dev team), AoTR is a complete revamp of the base game that drastically changes the gameplay of the Empire, Rebellion, and Black Sun (Renamed and recently revamped Consortium in 2.10) into an entirely new game in some aspects. Based on the pc game Star Wars: Rebellion, this mod adds many features from this game and other titles, including a more in-depth mission system, tech system, and many new units. AoTR also improves tactical combat in space, ground and galactic combat, and substantially improves the graphics of the base game. Also, if you play as the rebel alliance, be sure to say hello to the Captain of the Liberation for me, he's a great guy ;-)
(***NOTE***: This mod is not super well suited to newcomers to EaW or the mod, expect it to be difficult, I advise starting a small campaign on the lowest difficulty to learn the mechanics before jumping into a long and hard campaign).

EDIT: 2.11 has recently been announced, which is a total rework of the maps and some improvements across the board.


Empire At War Expanded Mods (EaWX): EaWX is a list of mods that completely change the base game into one of four Legends eras- Post-Endor (Thrawn's Revenge), Clone Wars (Fall of The Republic), Old Republic (Revan's Revenge), and Galactic Civil War (Imperial Reign). In addition to adding in new units and factions, there are several new mechanics in each mod that greatly improve the game and bring it into the modern world. New mechanics include resources (Food, Parts, Planetary Influence, Ship Crews, and Trade Ports), Imperial Legitimacy, Allied Factions in some mods, the ability to choose your heads-of-state and command staff, and many other smaller and bigger changes with their own uses throughout your campaign. For fans of canon, there is a submod that adds in the MC-75, Sphyrna-class Corvette (Hammerhead Corvette), and Starhawk-class. There is also a submod that allows for torpedoes and missiles to penetrate shields, but the standard EaWX mods have all weapons only hit shields until they can be brought offline, so if you dislike AoTR's ability to take out the engines of retreating enemy forces (or hate losing your own capitals like Home One to 2 bomber squadrons even with full shields), then this is a mod for you. There is so much more to these mods that I cannot even fully explain here, as I have too little space to write about them, so I'm going to tell you to try it for yourself. I would say these are probably some of the best mods for fans of EaW who want to challenge themselves. (***NOTE***: At the time of writing this, only Fall of The Republic and Thrawn's Revenge have been launched, with Revan's Revenge launching sometime between 2023-2024 and Imperial Reign being possibly 2+ years off from launching)

Empire At War Remake: Empire at War if it was launched in modern times instead of 2006, not only are there new models and even new units, there are new mechanics and new factions to play as. I personally have little experience with this mod, and as such I will not try to explain things that I do not 100% know, but I have heard entirely great reviews of it, and I advise you to check it out. (***WARNING***: make sure your computer can handle graphics really well, because this mod is REALLY laggy if your computer is a potato like my own)

EDIT: I have managed to acquire a computer that can actually run this mod, and I can wholeheartedly say I love it


Other mods include the Clone Wars extravaganza that is Republic at War (RaW), the ultimate meme- ***cough cough*** sorry, (force of habit) the EXPANSIVE and ACTION-PACKED Yoden Mod, and the thrilling and detailed Phoenix Rising mod, among the hundreds of others not mentioned here. There's something for everyone in the workshop!

Before I end this, I would like to shout out several content creators who I advise watching if you find yourself interested in any of these mods but want to find out more before trying them yourself. There's so many I could never list every single one here, but these are my personal favorites for EaW:

Coreyloses- EaWX developer, has several older and ongoing campaigns on the current and upcoming updates of the different EaWX mods.
The XPGamers (Captain Shack)- The YouTuber who actually brought EaW into my world, Shack has several AoTR, EaWX, and a handful of other mod playthroughs that I highly advise checking out if you find yourself interested in any mods listed.
GenesisKing- Another YouTuber that is another great choice for checking out mods. Very similar to Shack, Genesis King has many AoTR, EaWX, and other mod playthroughs.
Andrew Hester- An underrated YouTuber that definitely needs more subscribers, check him out for all sorts of mods and that are not even listed here. While you're there, say hello to Perkins ;-)

This game is an absolute labour of love from the wonderful folk at Petroglyph, who created this masterpiece in part with the expertise they developed while working as Westwood Studios before its untimely demise.
Even now almost 20 years after release on Steam, this game still gets substantial updates based on community feedback, the most recent of which went as far as switching the backend from 32-bit to 64-bit.

While the base game is a bit dated graphically, the gameplay still holds up, so much so that the game has an active modding community happily building upon it (which has also benefited greatly from the official updates), with some of the most popular overhauling the game to add different eras and settings, such as the Clone Wars or Stargate.

Featuring both single and multiplayer, space and land battles, as well as a Galactic Conquest style tactical layer where you build your empire, this game has a bit of something for everyone, and mods can add to which part it is you like most.
At the time of writing this review the game is £5.86, but it would still be a bargain at £60.

This is my favourite RTS and one of my favourite Star Wars games. Even in 2023, there is still a very active modding community continuing to make the game better and better. 

While some other RTS games string together battles on a world map which is turn based, the galactic map in this game plays out in real time-- this creates a sort of onion of real time strategy games, where land and space battles (which play very differently) happen inside of the galactic RTS.

For something that came out in 2006, this is a really really good RTS. If you ever have a particular scratch for skirmishes of fleet combat in the Star Wars universe, this scratches that itch quite well.

This game is actually made up of 2 games, the original Empire at War and its later sequel, Forces of Corruption. I can't say much about the original Empire at War other than that it seems like it had some balancing and combat issues, where units would not die quick enough and there wasn't much contrast in power between vehicles and infantry. There were also power scaling issues in space combat as well. Forces of Corruption fixed all of these issues and added more maps, more characters and units, more mechanics, and an entirely new faction called the Zann Consortium, a criminal underworld faction.

The main differences between the two games thematically are that the original game is set prior and a bit during the events of A New Hope, and Forces of Corruption is set after The Empire Strikes Back. Each of these games has a story-driven campaign involving each of the major factions. The original Empire at War has two campaigns, one for the Empire and one for the Rebels, whereas Forces of Corruption only has one for the Zann Consortium. One of the drawbacks of this game is that you can't actually play all three campaigns in Forces of Corruption, only the one for the Zann Consortium. There may be a mod to do that, but I'm not quite sure.

Speaking of the Zann Consortium, during any Galactic Conquest runthrough, they are incredibly unfun and annoying to deal with. They can corrupt star systems and allow them to steal daily income or bypass territory completely with fleets, and it costs money to get rid of corruption. Lots of their units seem to be incredibly overpowered and needlessly difficult to deal with as well given the nature of the game's rock paper scissors mechanics. There's also the Rebels' plex troopers which are good at killing almost literally everything.

Overall despite the lackluster ground combat and balance issues, this is a really really fun RTS. There's all sorts of fun mechanics like building structures on ground and space stations to produce units, individual unit abilities, heroes, tech upgrades, smuggling, bounty hunting, and territorial bonuses.

If you for whatever reason don't like the way the base game is, there's a massive amount of mods online and on the Steam Workshop which modify the game in various ways. One of the most popular mods is a total conversion Clone Wars mod called Republic at War.

If you like Star Wars and you like RTS games, I highly recommend this one.

An excellent Star Wars RTS game. Features both space and land battles. Economy is very simple, so if you're into complex economy it's not going to be your thing, but the battles themselves on land and space are satisfying. There are plenty planets featured from the movie and you'll be even able to see how Alderaan looked like before it was destroyed (;_;) 

Without mods, you can only play in era of Episode 4-6 as Rebels, Empire and as Zann's Consortium (some kind of space mafia faction roughly summarized). Zann's Consortium can also be disabled which I honestly prefer. I prefer the classic storyline of Empire and Rebels. The victory outro for both is really satisfying by the way.

The only downside I would say is that the graphics look really dated but that can be fixed as I said by certain mods.

You're very likely not going to be disappointed.

Oh man, this game is my childhood. Nostalgia may slightly blind me but kid me has always had some gripes with this game. So not as blind as you might think...

Firstly, this is a game I got from a school catalogue which I think came with some magazine or something, I don't entirely remember what. I was at the time mourning losing my Battlefront 2 disc, which had incredible nostalgia for me as well but this game helped me cope with that. At first I barely knew how to do anything I think I loaded up a Skirmish on Naboo as the Empire with a bunch of allies on both sides, and I just used the fee units since I had no idea how to click on the buildings apparently. This was my very first RTS however so my sillyness can be forgiven. :P

But that was my first fond memories. I have many many fond memories, this game ran well on my laptop so it was my go too game on roadtrips and in many situations. I played on easy mpst of the time since AI scares me. On easy it feels like you almost become a sadistic torturer of your enemies toying with them. Which I certainly played into as the Empire. But the question is... What does this say about the game? Well aside from the fact I have played this game for countless hours on disc on to of what I have on Steam and how fomd of this game I am... Not too much.

Gamemodes:
Tutorial
Campaign
Galactic Conquest
Skirmish (land)
Skirmish (space)
Skirmish (land control)

I honestly haven't played land control much. I would honestly like to try but most of my experience is split between the other modes so I will talk about my dislikes for each. Which isn't to say I am saying it's bad, it's just that asking me to say what exactly I like about this game is like asking someone why they love a song. I don't know I just like it. There is many reasons which I simply couldn't articulate. So I will focus on dislikes because there is a few key things I feel is missing.

TUTORIAL:

Well, what is there to say? Play them! :P

Notably if you ever wish to play the Campaign for Forces of Corruption please do play the FoC specifc Tutorials because it includes what I would call the prologue. The game files call it that at least. Don't miss out on them! 

CAMPAIGN:

For the camapigns, I have very little against them. They are great, and I don't remember having too many issues with them. However the one thing I do dislike is the fact that you can't play the Non-DLC camapigns in FoC. It makes sense why ofc, but I think it would be cool if you could play them still. But luckily you can by just... Opening the non-DLC game. Which I argue has a better title screen by far.

GALACTIC CONQUEST:

In the non-FoC version of this, there is occasionally missions you can get from the various military leaders. I think that they are sorely missed in FoC. Especially because it has cool voice acting. It honestly baffles me and has forever bothered me that they were taken out in FoC.

The Consortium... This will become a trend but the  Consortium in Galactic Conquest feels... Cheesey. I love the additions in FoC, but I honestly wish there was a way to customise the galacy a bit more in regards ro spawns. There is already a bunch of presets, but honestly I wish there was something like Equal Footing but... Incredibly inequal. Like this around the time of tESB to RotJ, so it makes sense the Rebels don't have like two planets, but I would like the Consortium to mostly be consolidated around Hutt and Mandalorian space. Meaning that the most OP faction by far is in the weakest position galaxy wise. I also wish there was an option to turn the Consortium off. Yes I know there is mods which fix all of these problems... But it wouldn't be a very proper review of the game if I included things which players have done to it. (Which mods certainly do fix a lot of issues, and create a bunch of new ones)

SKIRMISH LAND:

Skirmish is interesting but I will include land based objections in here too. EaW is a departure from traditional style RTS's when it comes to base building. As in everyone starts off with two forts with equal footing against each other. You can make it so you have to construct the buoldings but it's a lot more like you all just got bombed and need to rebuild for war asap. You get free units if you so choose which is just two units of infantry which probably contain either two or three squads each. I think the main issue of land battles in Empire at War is mainly down to the fact that Galactic Conquest kinda corrupt peoples opinions on land battles. Because in GC you can just spam something and win. But I don't think I am aware of a strategy game wjich doesn't have that same issue... Well maybe some but horde tactics tend to work in most RTS's. Skirmish land is a better experience than land in GC for sure. And any mods which try to "fix" land battles basically turn it into a giant spectle slug match where the strongest unit wins and the weakest losses. Perhaps I am a little attached. But what I am not attached to is the fact that the Consortium has extremely overpowered turrets. And well most of their things are. Playing the consortium is basically playing the galaxies largest Troll compilation video. Legend says that under the mask of a defiler you will find a Troll face straight from 2012. Why? Defilers got trained by the IRA. And using IRA like tactics is incredibly easy when... You have cloaking technology. I haven't even mentioned Ewok Handlers. Like I ain't hating on the Consortium because I think it's an overpowered faction... I hate the consortium when I am not playing as them. Lol

SKIRMISH SPACE:

Space! The final fron... Sorry, wrong universe. But I think there is a mod for that.

Space is the bread and butter of this game. In fact it is so much so that the most annoying land unit in the game behaves like one! (DAMN YOU GARM!!)

I struggle to really find anything I dislike about space battles. I think it's sad Darth Vader doesn't have his Super Star Destroyer like he does in GC... But I entirely understand why. Speaking of which, I wish GC FoC Luke appeared in skirmish battles on space he has a unique X-Wing which is is pretty strong but tbh I also think it would be OP. The Skywalkers are too strong... That's why they must not had included Leia... :(

Which reminds me I dislike how neither Lando or Leia made it in the game. Very sadge... :(

I would like to say tho, the Consortium in space is far more balanced than their land counterpart. Like for instance their superweapon is mounted on the station. I kinda forgot to mention superweapons but oh well. The Empire has the best one by far tho. On both land and in space.

SKIRMISH LAND CONTROL:

I already said I wouldn't talk about this but just adding it to say, it would be nice if there was a space version of this mode. Or even a GC mode which functioned based on controlling certain planets for a certain amount of time. It would be very chaotic and fun.

CONCLUSION:

I am not a very good reviewer. But I just spent an hour typing about a game I love. I guess you could call it... A love letter... Ey? No? Oh okay.

Regardless, this game has imprinted itself into my mind and the most memorable thing for me is when pilots are screaming and dying mostly because I sent them to their deaths for not very effective tactical faints. Also...

WE'VE JUST LOST OUR LAND BAYS! WE'VE JUST LOST OUR SHIELD GENERATOR! THEY'RE TOO MANY OF TH-ARRRGGGGHHHHH! ANYONE ELSE SEE THEM!

Oh and of course the screaming roar of TIE Fighters. All burnt into my brain. Just like the Forces of Corruption title music. :P

Random Steam user who read this, I sincerely apologise for subjecting you to this rant. Now please do go and enjoy this game. And I swear by Akbar that if Disney doesn't allow Petroglyph to make a sequel... I will recreate Disneyworld in the editor and blow it all up with Defilers! And maybe also Ewok Handlers... And heck why not throw in a few Rancors or two. And then take over Florida. Tyber Zann for President!

I have played this game for years, long before I had steam, and there are some games I've played on another account. I have a few things to say.

The game is great, there are 3 campaign stories between the base game and expansion, there is still multiplayer, people are still making new mods for the game, there's a galactic conquest, skirmish mode, there is still so much for this game all these years later. To play the campaigns you'll have to boot up different versions as steam treats them differently.

There are issues with the game.

If you save during a battle and try to load it later it can have issues loading. it isn't so bad at first but for very large battles or for battles in a galactic conquests that's gone on for a while it's unreliable. it's not an issue outside of combat so you'll be fine just doing that.

There is also a problem with saves in multiplayer where you'r save won't show up, I don't have a fix for this and don't know if there is one but that only effects galactic conquest in multiplayer.

The game is fun, and it's Star Wars.

STAR WARS™ Empire at War - Gold Pack, developed by Petroglyph and published by LucasArts, is a strategy game that invites players to immerse themselves in the iconic Star Wars universe. Released in 2006, this classic title allows you to command the forces of the Galactic Empire or the Rebel Alliance in epic space and ground battles. As a longtime fan of the Star Wars franchise, I'm excited to share my detailed review of this beloved strategy gem.

Gameplay (9/10):
Empire at War offers a compelling mix of real-time strategy and tactical combat. Players can engage in both space and ground battles, each with its own set of units, tactics, and objectives. The game allows for the construction of fleets and armies, the management of resources, and the development of planets. The galactic map provides strategic depth as you vie for control of star systems. The gameplay is accessible to newcomers while offering depth and complexity for strategy enthusiasts.

Storytelling (8/10):
Empire at War provides an engaging narrative set in the Star Wars universe during the Galactic Civil War. The game's campaign mode presents the conflict from the perspectives of both the Rebel Alliance and the Galactic Empire. While the story doesn't deviate significantly from the established lore, it allows players to participate in key events and make strategic decisions that impact the outcome of the war. The inclusion of iconic characters and voice acting adds to the immersion.

Galactic Conflict (9/10):
The heart of Empire at War lies in its depiction of the ongoing struggle between the Empire and the Rebel Alliance. The galactic map is the battleground, and players must make strategic choices about which planets to conquer, defend, or invest in. The dynamic nature of the conflict ensures that no two campaigns play out the same way. The ability to engage in both space and ground battles adds variety and depth to the strategic gameplay.

Graphics and Sound (7/10):
Considering its release in 2006, Empire at War's graphics have aged reasonably well. The space battles are visually impressive, with detailed ship models and engaging combat animations. Ground battles, while less polished, still capture the essence of Star Wars battles. The game features iconic Star Wars sound effects and music, immersing players in the familiar audio landscape of the franchise.

Modding Community (10/10):
One of Empire at War's enduring strengths is its robust modding community. The game's modding tools and support for user-generated content have led to the creation of countless mods that enhance and expand the game. From total conversions that transport players to different eras of the Star Wars universe to smaller enhancements, the modding community has breathed new life into Empire at War, ensuring its continued relevance.

STAR WARS™ Empire at War - Gold Pack, while not as well-known as some other Star Wars games, has a dedicated fanbase and has demonstrated the potential for strategy games set in the Star Wars universe. Its influence can be seen in subsequent Star Wars titles that explore similar gameplay mechanics.

My time with Empire at War has been a journey through the Star Wars universe, commanding fleets, conquering planets, and reliving iconic battles. The game's modding community has kept the experience fresh and exciting, allowing me to explore alternate Star Wars scenarios and eras. Empire at War remains a cherished part of my gaming collection.

STAR WARS™ Empire at War - Gold Pack is a strategy classic that invites players to immerse themselves in the epic conflict of the Star Wars universe. Its engaging gameplay, dynamic galactic conflict, and enduring modding community ensure its place in the hearts of Star Wars fans and strategy enthusiasts alike. Whether you're leading the Empire to dominance or fighting for the Rebel Alliance, Empire at War offers an unforgettable journey through a galaxy far, far away.

this game looked fun in theory. im a big rts fan, whether it be total war, mount and blade, hoi, halo wars, whatever. i love building armies and fighting wars. and ive always wanted to do it in star wars, especially with the idea of space combat. unfortunately this game does not live up to the hype. It is old and dated, even moreso than other older rts'. The learning curve is insane, and while the tutorial does a decent enough job of teaching you the basics, it hardly  teaches you enough to play this game and succeed. The difficulty is also insane. the lowest difficulty feels like it should be the hardest in any other game, and i dread to think what the higher difficulties are like. It drops you into a galaxy where you are underarmed and undersupplied, not nearly having enough troops to fend for yourself in the long term. and sure, you can make more, but the game never teaches you how to do so in a sustainable manner. The enemy AI is relentless, and not in a good way. You will be constantly assaulted by humongous ass fleets while yours is nowhere near the others level, so all you can do is retreat your forces away, and thats if the game even lets you. Sure you might take a planet or two here and there, but for every one step forward you take its 4 steps backwards. It feels like whenever im finished running away from or getting my ass kicked in a battle the game starts yelling in my face about ANOTHER massive fleet thats invading another system. Its insane, borderline unplayable. If there were mods that reduced the INSANE difficulty of this game then maybe id recommend it, and if there are feel free to let me know, but as the game is, i can try to learn how the fuck to manage it, but i wouldnt recommend anyone else doing so.

Ok, I wanted to love this game I really did.  Ok First things first.  Yes it's a big galaxy strategy game of Star wars, you can build fleets and armies, have land and space battles, build star destroyers etc, it's all there.
BUT: When I'm playing it I'm thinking, for every thing the game does well, there's two things that crop up that make me think, 'rebellion did this better six years earlier'.
1)You get limited 'command points' so that the biggest battle you get is about 5 star destroyers... if you have 20, fine, they come in one at a time as reinforcements.
2) Ships repair automatically, so if you cripple a ship in a hit and fade mission, eg, you play as rebels, fly in blast a big star destroyer, fly out then your main fleet comes in just after, literally 1 second can transpire, which represents maybe 1/12 of a galactic day, and that ship will be completely fixed.  So anything you don't destroy is immediately repaired.  That seems like basic logic has gone WAY out the window.
3) You can not sabotage anything, you can only steal technology as the rebels, so usig spec forces or whatever doesn't come into it all.
4) Ground battles are  alittle repetitive, and if for eg, you take over a planet, you can't build defences on the ground level until a battle starts... WHAT THE HELL! So eg you can build BIG things like Ion cannons or shields for the planet, but little 'build pads' for local defences to help you shoot down AT-AT's or whatever can't be built until an invading army arrives... what was my army doing for the six months I held that planet, just standing there? Then they go.. 'oh right, the enemy is landing, maybe we shouldn't have been just giving each other piggy back rides this whole time...'

These might sound niggly as problems, and  they are, but they and a few more I wont mention REALLy pile up to hold the game back from being great. 
The story is paper thin, leads up to the destruction of the 1st death star in star wars 1977.

THE EXPANSION PACK:
In short, it fixes about three little problems, much improved story campaign, you can now sabotage and do things like that BUT ONLY WITH THE NEW TEAM, but the issues above are still largely present.
And when you play games with all 3 teams (ie NOT the campaign) You can see how balance was not an issue for the developers.
The new team, the pirates are SO overpowered and will absolutely cripple the rebs and imps, so play as them or get angry, that's your choices.

So overall, yes I do recommend it, you can see by my hours played that I still gave it a go, and the expansion definitely improves the game enough to give it some reply value. ( I got a MOD with some maps, so I could play the expansion on old maps WITHOUT the new pirate team, thus it wasn't so unabalanced, but could play with the new features, ships etc)

Star Wars Empire at War - A game I have been playing since around release of Forces of Corruption using an old disc copy of the game. If you're looking for a Star wars RTS, it does NOT get much better then this classic. The base game is decent enough but it shines much brighter with the Forces of Corruption expansion, the expansion brings with it an exceptional modding community that will give you what feels like endless hours of replayability. In my opinion the base game with expansion is quite solid with decent enough graphics and gameplay, fun combat and a also decent amount of variety to immerse yourself in this Star Wars RTS. However once again I must come back to the mods of this game, Awakening of the Rebellion, Imperial civil War, The Remake mod, Republic at War (Etc..). this game stands at an entirely different level if you decide to explore what the modding community has to offer. Highly Highly recommend this game if you like the sound of a Star Wars RTS that's easy to learn but hard to master all for a really good price that requires a potato of a PC to run (Some mods may up graphical fidelity and require better hardware) 9.5/10 would recommend everytime.

Star Wars + real time strategy + strategic gameplay? A winning combo in my humble opinion :P In addition to fighting real time battles over planets and in space, there is a campaign mode with a map where the player can plan which planet to attack, which production structures to build, and planetary defences. Planets have natives allied to the different sides that will help that side in any battle there (Rebellion/Empire/Zhan Consortion) and also provide unique bonuses for whoever controls them.

The bundle also comes with 3 full campaigns, the third culminating in the player controlling a Eclipse-class super star destroyer complete with it's very own anti-ship superlaser. Not to mention that the Empire can build the Death Star itself and use it to destroy enemy planets.

Also, X-wings, lightsabers, and Darth Vader.

Why don't you have this game? RATING: 9.5/10

The best star wars game on the market! Such a classic and even 17yrs later is being given new life by an incredible modding community. While battlefront let's you feel like an individual trooper in the star wars galaxy, Empire at War lets you feel like a commander in the galactic civil war. It allows the player to experience the conflicts that never made it to the big screen both on land and in space. The space battles are the highlight of the game for sure, it never gets old watching dogfights between Tie Fighters and X Wings unfold as a Star Destroyer drops out of Hyperspace and into battle over a planet! Until the day Empire at War gets a proper sequel (please video game gods), this triumph of a game is an excellent way to experience the grand Star Wars galaxy for any RTS, Star Wars, or Strategy game fan!

Before the dark times... before the Disney acquisition.... 

What more can be said about Empire at War? It is an incredible RTS game period. Sure ground combat is kinda meh, but who cares, THE BIG HULKING STAR DESTROYERS IS WHERE IT'S AT BABY! The Vanilla game is extremely fun and can entertain you for years and years. It did for me. If I had to choose 3 games to play for the rest of my life, this would be one of them. Where this game truly shines for me now though, is the absolutely incredible modding scene that's still strong, almost approaching two decades after the release of this perfect gem. Plus, Petroglyph, the absolute legends they are, are still doing occasional updates and bug fixes and supporting modders. 

If you like Star Wars, or RTS games, or hell, if you're alive, buy this. On sale or not, it's worth every dollar.

This game is great. However, to really appreciate the game, you need to pick up one of the big mods. But the game is good on it's own as well. You can play as either the Rebels or Empire. With the Gold Pack though, you also get a third faction.
Imagine you are in a huge battle in Return of the Jedi. You are playing as the rebels and you are getting destroyed by the Empire. You've tried everything else. The X-Wings and all the way up to the Mid-size frigate. But then, you get the last upgrade to your command center. You can now spawn a full blown battleship that can take on a Star Destroyer. It's satisfying.
Game also has ground battles. To me, those are less interesting, but you get to storm a rebel base with a company of Stormtroopers. Or rebels. Take your pick. Heroes also exist. They are characters that can only have one of each on the field. They include Darth Vader, Emperor Palpatine, Luke, Leia, Han, and Chebacca. Some of these also get ships in space battles. For instance, Han and Chewbacca fly the Millennium Falcon as the rebels. Meanwhile, Vader gets his Tie Fighter.

This game besides the age it is, the game definitely holds up. The vanilla game it's self is overall pretty decent. From the original empire at war playing as the pesky Rebels fighting against the domination of the Empire. the "3rd" faction the pirates give a buffer like effect between you and the opposing faction. Now forces of corruption introduces the official 3rd faction the Zahn Consortium, a pirate/underworld faction. The introduction of this factions introduces the player to new mechanics such as a multi-choice corruption mechanic and the corruption missions that come with it. These corruption missions are fairly easy and can span from kidnapping, piracy, and intimidation. Now the interesting thing about this mechanic that it adds perks such as bribery, which disables the "neutral" or "civilian" forces from aiding against you, to racketeering which can give you a more than decent income bump. To the considered to be over powered revolt which when the player attempts to remove the corruption instead of it going away the planet "revolts" and becomes neutral, either Empire or Rebels. Now the last two mechanics really add something for me, the slavery and piracy. There are certain planets that can allow you to enslave the locals and make like in the games terms "cannon-fodder" army. Piracy depending on which planet it is can add units of either Rebel or Empire to your roster such as A wings to an Acclamator cruiser. Now for the down sides. The vanilla games after a couple play throughs can get a little stale and unit death stacks (strategy which can be OP) can ruin the experience. Path finding as seen in most real time strategy games can be a little infuriating especially in space combat. But the biggest one i've seen that i forgot to mention is the sabotage mechanic which pay a few credits and unit sacrifice can make a multi defense structured planet be broken down to a single structure. Besides other bugs and mishaps the biggest bonus of this game is the modding community. I along with hundreds of other players can agree that the modding community has gotten so much better since its addition of the steam workshop. Mods such as Thrawns Revenge and the Empire at War Remake mods completely convert from the base game and in a way become a whole new game in its self. From the mods to the gameplay its self, and to the usually really cheap price tag. The game is a must buy for any Star Wars fan or an RTS buff who wants a new challenge. This game has brought me hours upon hours of fun and i really hope someone else can find the same excitement and enjoyment from a must buy, cult classic game!

[b]tldr;
amazing game, runs on anything, hours and hours of content and if somehow u got bored or you can't stand a lil retro look - just throw the Workshop at it till you struggle to run it anymore![/b]

[b]Amazing game, tons of fun.[/b] I'm not an RTS person, but I am a Star Wars person and defnitely a Star Wars Legends person and this game hits the spot very nicely. There is a vibe to this game, especially with the Forces of Corruption (FoC) DLC that is very Star Wars Legends, some ships, maps, SFX, voice acting, characters and trivia about planets will make every Star Wars nerd happy!

On top of that it's just a very good game, good looking (for 2006 ofc), [b]great performance with tons and tons of way to play with just vanilla and FoC DLC content[/b] - 3 factions, tons of planets, tons of unique planetary battle locations, tons of unit types ([i]you can enslave Ewoks and make them into kamikaze bombs, which is... uhh[/i]), game types, etc. 

But it can get repetetive after almost 70h of this... [b]which is where the Workshop comes in![/b]
Not enough Star Destroyers on your screen? Triple your unit cap! F*** it, make it infinite, till there's no more room for calling in reinforcements!
Wanna make your game look 10x more modern? Sure! There's some graphical mods that will make your PC cry!
But where's the fun in just looks and more units? Want 5 times the unit types? Complicated tech trees? A galaxy with 200 planets instead 50? Mechanics that requires reading a wiki or two? A whole new campaign story? 10 whole new campaign stories? Complicated tech trees? New factions? How about ditching those old 70-80s Rebels and Empire stuff for old people (im kidding obviously) and pitting some roger-roger-ahh Battle Droids against The Clone Army? [i]Did I mention complicated and tech trees?[/i]
Just go to the Workshop, sort by most popular and subscribe away! You got bored with that? Yeah sure, like I'll believe that- but, just go check again, one of the 5 complete overhaul mods you just downloaded just probably got a massive update with 15 new unit types, new mechanics and probably like 5 new factions (those people work hard on those mods!).

A simple RTS within the Star Wars Universe. With or without the Forces of the Corruption expansion, this game is awesome.

That being said, this game is not without its flaws. It's fairly dated and not as complex as compared to PC RTSs today. 

Campaigns:
-Rebellion: Great faction...with their Raid ability. Testing one's capability to work with little to take a lot.
-Empire: Awesome faction. Bigger is better. Don't let the tiny X-wing main character scare you.
-Zann Consortium: Interesting faction. Bottom line? Make ALL the money. You won't be able to pay for all those nice shiny ships and toys without an Emperor's ransom.

Multiplayer:
-If you can find another willing to play, great. Though, I hear the Consortium is overpowered in multiplayer. ;)

Overall, I give this game a 9/10. Dated, but still enjoyable to new and experienced RTS players, plus.... it's Star Wars, before the Disney takeover.

If you do the largest galactic conquest as the rebels/empire on hard mode, it is nearly impossible to win in a reasonable time frame, you will be playing for a lifetime if you want to complete the conquest completely. I have done one galactic conquest for each side on hard mode (the largest version). Playing as the Zann consortium, I won an entire galactic conquest in about 3 hours - it is way too easy as them. Playing as the empire it is a little more do-able but expect to put way too much time in. As the rebels, it is nearly impossible unless you blitzkrieg the empire right away, if you don't the consortium will take over the empire nearly completely in about 40 "game days". The DLC is meant to be played as the Zann consortium and not rebels or empire. The Zann consortium side is ridiculously overpowered. They are perfect with how smart they are and the DLC actually learns your tactics which is pretty cool but the zann consortium was definetely made wayyyy too strong. There should be an option to also have it just be the rebels and empire again as well (not like the original) but with all the new add-ons. I ended up quitting as the rebels and empire and did not finish because I got too frusterated with how overpowered they were.

So this is basically Star Wars: Total War, with some nice help from some C&C devs.
Some things I really like:
-You can rename ships by editing a text file
-You can use the old C&C style mouse controls with a single tickbox
-You can run over infantry with vehicles, ala C&C
-Mods like Fall of the Republic and Rise of the Mandalorians

I can't think of many things to critique, though adjusting to the 4X/TW formula is a bit much. You should also know that the overview map isn't turn based, all RTS all the time.

UPDATE: Now that I've completed all 3 campaigns, and am most of the way through my first FoC Galactic Conquest, I have some notes:
-Instead of making the Emperor run around to purge corruption, it would've been nice to instead have "ant-Corruption" units, like ISB Agents for the Empire.
-Most hyperlanes are invisible, which can cause stratagem problems. A simple solution is just to have trade lanes be double lines, and normal lanes single (or dotted and solid, respectively)
-Hero unit spam. So far, half my encounters with Alliance space forces and nearly every invasion have involved enemy Hero units (I've literally lost count of how many times I've blown up Home One). Gunning down Heroes should be hard, but permanent, imo. Bounty Hunters could simply function as-is, but if a Hero is lost, it's permanent.
--Sub-note: FoC Heroes need attention. Tarkin, Sundered Heart, and Obi-Wan are all dead at this point and need replacements. You can kind of squint and give Boba a pass, but the others are 100% not usable.
-The Corrupt Militia Corruption option is a great nuisance, and not much else. No suggestions for a replacement.
-It would be nice if you could set Galaxy Map filters as a persistent setting, as well as saving scout unit placements.
-The Empire feels a bit like playing on a harder game mode, allow me to explain:
--The Alliance gets airspeeders at Tech 1 or 2, for which the Empire has a single counter for (turret pads) until Tech 4. The Alliance can also just ignore space combat and land some pretty hefty units directly on the planet.
--The Consortium has counters for airspeeders with their MDUs, and can basically shop for planet bonuses, instead of having to clear every planet (though GC probably won't count that as a "win", Zann's functionally won).
--By comparison, the Empire has to clear every planet, do every fight, and deal with hard counters to a lot of their stuff until Tech 4. Their only advantage is one-button Tech upgrades and "space carriers" (everything from the Acclamator up doubles as a carrier, iirc).

Both are in my opinion the way the game should've been and is the reasoning for myself picking this game up again. So what side will you pick?

I recently had the pleasure of diving into the immersive world of STAR WARS™ Empire at War - Gold Pack, and I must say, it exceeded all my expectations. This game is a true gem

With its three captivating campaigns, a dozen turn-based conquest modes, and classic skirmish battles, this game offers an incredible amount of content that will keep you engaged for hours on end. The longevity it offers is truly impressive, ensuring that every penny spent on this game is worth it.

Now, as an experienced RTS fan, I understand the importance of a balanced and precise gameplay experience. While the ground battles in Empire at War may have their shortcomings in terms of unit controls and balance, the real star of the show lies in its magnificent space battles. Here, the game truly shines, providing an awe-inspiring galactic-scale RTS experience that is second to none.

The attention to detail in the space battles is remarkable. Each class of ship serves a purpose, and the expanded Ship limit allows for grand, strategic maneuvers that will leave you breathless. Whether you're commanding iconic vessels from the movies or exploring the depths of the Star Wars lore and comics with lesser-known ships and races, the variety and depth of the space combat are simply outstanding.

Furthermore, Empire at War opens up a world of possibilities beyond the vanilla game with its vibrant modding community. Projects like Revenge of Thrawn and Republic at War introduce a plethora of new units that will delight even the most die-hard Star Wars fans. These mods breathe new life into the game, offering fresh experiences and expanding the already vast content available.

While some may argue that the graphics have aged, I assure you that it's a minor concern. In space combat, where the action primarily takes place, the visuals are more than satisfactory. The level of detail on planets is commendable, and it holds its own when compared to modern RTS games. The solid game engine and the immense fun factor quickly overshadow any visual shortcomings.

What sets Empire at War apart from other games in the genre is its accessibility. The learning curve is relatively low, allowing both casual players and hardcore RTS enthusiasts to jump right into the action. As you progress, you'll find yourself devising complex conquest plans on the galactic map, strategizing and conquering with ease.

The game's space combat mechanics are particularly impressive, offering unique features like Hardpoints and Unit Abilities. Targeting specific systems adds a layer of tactical depth, allowing you to disable enemy ships strategically. Unit Abilities provide opportunities to gain the upper hand in combat, adding excitement and variety to each engagement.

I must admit that the base game's ground combat may not be as captivating, with limited units and visually uninteresting elements.

In conclusion, STAR WARS™ Empire at War - Gold Pack is an exceptional game that immerses you in the vastness of the Star Wars universe. Despite its age, it remains a timeless classic, providing endless hours of entertainment. The space combat alone is worth the investment, and with the addition of mods, the game reaches new heights. If you're a Star Wars fan or an RTS enthusiast looking for an addictive and captivating experience, this game is an absolute must-play.

May the Force be with you as you embark on your galactic conquests!

Honestly, I can't say much about the base game cuz I never played it. This is because the mods for this game ARE JUST SO DAMN GOOD MAN. And its just so easy to mod this game through the workshop.

If you're a casual or hardcore Star Wars fan and dream of commanding your own fleets and channelling your inner-Admiral Thrawn, please pick up this game. 

Its described as an RTS but it ain't as stressful as say Starcraft. You can turn this game into a casual Star Wars power fantasy, or you can recreate the same stress Palpatine had after hearing about the Death Star's destruction. I will say though...space battles are just 10x better than ground battles. Now lets talk mods.

EAW: Remake 4.0 is the most graphically impressive of the bunch. IMO its the most immersive of the significant mods you'll find. The space battles are grandiose and the scale of your ships from star-fighters to dreadnoughts is fantastic. You can even download EAW: Remake 3.5 Revisited if you want the fidelity of 4.0 without the ground battles of 4.0. However, this mod is DEFINITELY easier than the other significant mods. When you get the hang of the game and start bum-rushing planets, your power snowballs in the endgame. By this point, the AI won't not stand a chance against you unless you AFK for while, and even then. 

Thrawn's Revenge fixes this snowball effect with Cruel AI while also providing more complex mechanics. However, the mod trades these things with graphical fidelity. I mean, the mod is still gorgeous but when you play Remake first you kind of miss the textures.

I can't say anything for Awakening of the Rebellion, Fall of the Republic, or Yoden, but I heard those were good mods as well.

Overall, HIGHLY recommend the game.
