[h1]STAR WARS™ Empire at War - Gold Pack[/h1]
STAR WARS™ Empire at War - Gold Pack is an RTS game that allows us to experience the events of the Original Trilogy in space and on planetary surfaces as one of three factions; Galactic Empire, Rebel Alliance and Zann Consortium.
[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Before starting the campaign, we have two modes to choose from; story campaign for each of the factions mentioned above, and the main sanbox mode, allowing us to play freely on many maps, representing different scenarios. Each faction has different gameplay styles, heroes, units, and buildings. We start our campaign on the galactic map, where we decide on the expansion of buildings on our planets, and on the construction of space stations, which allows us to develop the economy, army and navy. The game is not overwhelming and has enough content to enjoy without getting tired, and the main enjoyment are of course the space battles which are truly epic and well done. Battles on planetary surfaces are pretty unimpressive though. The buildings are quite sparse, the units feel wooden and a bit unresponsive, and the maps themselves are quite small. Not to mention that for Star Wars battles, enemy units are often painstaking damage sponges. It could be better, but it's not bad. The gameplay is certainly not revolutionary, however, it is still a lot of fun.
[h1]Technical Matters[/h1]
The game is stable and I haven't had any problems with it. As for the music, it's from the Original Trilogy, so of course it's top notch. However, moving on to the graphics, it's bad by today's standards, the textures either have a strange resolution, poor quality or are just strangely blurry. The visual effects aren't the best either, but at least they're decent, especially in space. And I would like to point out the voice actors who I think are quite meh. For the most part, I feel like they've been mismatched, plus with poor audio reception and transmission, the characters sound pretty weird.
[h1]Summary[/h1]
A very good game that, although not very deep and revolutionary, is a really good source of fun, and I hope there will be more such games based on the Star Wars universe. This is definitely one of those games that respects your time, which is a really rare phenomenon these days.

A timeless classic that bridges the gap between RTS gaming and the Star Wars universe. The game strikes a fantastic balance between ground and space battles, each featuring a unique set of mechanics and units that provide a well-rounded experience. The strategic layer is complex, yet intuitive, allowing you to move your forces across the galaxy and expand your empire.

The graphics, while not state-of-the-art, have aged well, maintaining a nostalgic aesthetic that brings players back to the mid-2000s. The sound design, which incorporates classic Star Wars music and sound effects, truly makes you feel as though you're directing the fate of a galaxy far, far away.

One thing to be aware of is that AI can be quite challenging, even in lower difficulty settings. While this does make for engaging and stimulating gameplay, less experienced players may find this frustrating.

The modding community surrounding this game is incredibly dedicated, and the availability of mods adds tremendous replay value. From total conversions that introduce new eras and factions to smaller mods that enhance the gameplay and graphics, there's no shortage of ways to customize and expand your Empire at War experience.

Solid strategy mechanics, engaging campaigns, and that unmistakable Star Wars charm. Despite showing its age in certain areas, I recommend Empire at War to both Star Wars fans and RTS enthusiasts. It's an experience that every RTS lover should try at least once.

This was the first real time strategy game I ever played. It was also the first Star Wars game I ever played. Between the original CD copy, the steam release, and the multitude of excellent community mods I've put an ungodly amount of time into the game and I don't think I'll ever stop playing. This game was released during the peak of Star Wars video games coming out close to Battlefront 2, Republic Commando, and KOTOR 2. While all those games are excellent, to me this is the ultimate Star Wars experience. It captures the scale of the universe like no other game has ever attempted. To be honest, I don't think I'd be a Star Wars fan without it.

The gameplay is asymmetric and each faction has their own strengths and weaknesses, and all of them can be staggeringly strong in the right situations. In the best format: galactic conquest you will be fighting in space and on land to control planets in the galaxy. The galactic map aspect feels more like a streamlined 4x game where you build structures and space stations which are used to build troops and research technology. Then you use the fleets and armies you've created to attack an enemy planet in a real time strategy battle. You can only use the units you've actually sent into the system in these battles giving a real sense of place to the entire game. Each faction has their own fully fleshed out single player campaign, but galactic conquest can also be played in multiplayer with 2 players (or 3 if you are using a mod) for a one-of-a-kind experience with friends. Watch Bokoen's Empire at War videos to get a sense of what this will be like. Everyone playing is going to have a fun time with unlikely victories, agonizing losses, and WTF moments. The game has so much soul to it and it's clear the developers poured their love of Star Wars into it. Even the tutorials have a fun little narrative! That's how much care and attention was put into this game.

The modding scene for this game is very active and there are a lot of high profile total conversion mods to bring the game into the clone wars, the post-endor period, and some mods which even remake the game with new mechanics. The amount of graphical fidelity and gameplay enhancements these mods are able to make based on a game from 2006 is truly mind boggling. I'd estimate that half my total time with this game was spent solely on Thrawn's Revenge.

For $20 (or less since old Star Wars games frequently go on sale) there is a monstrous amount of fun to be had here, and it's easy to learn as well. In a climate where game releases are frequently expensive, buggy, and very corporate feeling there's never been a better time to take a look back and try an old classic. If anything in this review has sounded interesting, I think you should at least take a closer look and seriously consider it.

There's a few reasons why I have 1000+ hours in this game, two of the main ones being its replayability and it's easy to learn mechanics. I have trouble getting into Real Time Strategy games as their game mechanics are often complicated and hard to get the hang of. Not here. It's extremely easy to get into for people who have never played one before, me included, and you get to command Star Destroyers, AT-ATs, and even the Death Star which is both capable of destroying planets and larger ships in a space battle. Even if you’re new to Star Wars, its dictionary of planets as you invade them and its description of ships, infantry, and vehicles will more than help you learn. Just by playing this game I quickly knew more about Star Wars than many of my friends who got me into it in middle school.

The length you can mod the game is amongst the best I’ve ever seen, right up there with Garry’s Mod and Minecraft. Have you gotten bored of the vanilla campaign? Pick one of the 329 mods in the workshop to turn the game into a new experience. With how easy it is to mod the game, you can even easily tweak mods to fit the experience you want. You can even mix-match mods together if you wanted to, even to the point of basically making your own without any programming or 3D modeling knowledge.

The game was a cult classic from the moment it came out. With an average playtime on Steam per player being 237 hours, 97% positive reviews, and an average of 2,500 players online at all times, it’s needless to say this game is loved to this day despite being 17 years old. Over time, a loyal community revolving around modding formed, to the point where the original developers updated the game a few times between 2019 and 2021. Around that time, the now united community around it had started doing everything from holding tournaments to collaborating with the creators of the most popular mods to help improve them. To this very day, fans of the game pester Disney with a remake as much as they can, and even got in contact with the original developers who said they’d be more than happy to if it got greenlit. 

The game can be laggy sometimes, but that's what happens when you use modern hardware on a game from 2006. With how good the immersion is despite its age, you won't really notice it once you're hooked into a campaign. You can also practice in small spurts by doing just a space battle or just a land battle that ends when one side wins, allowing you to replay it over and over again before you jump into a Galactic Conquest campaign, my favorite aspect of the game, period.

I picked it up years ago as a kid when I got a $20 Steam card for Christmas, and it was on sale for $5, as well as a bunch of other games. From the ease of access to new players, the easy to use modding support, to the huge community that still exists around it, I've never once regretted buying it. The community loves the 17 year old game so much that we've been pestering Disney for a remake for years now, and all of us await that day patiently. You won't regret picking it up during a sale, I guarantee it. You’ll enjoy every minute of it.

I don’t really do reviews on Steam, but I love this game enough to add to that 97% of positive user reviews.

It's a great game by itself. The mod scene has made it legendary and very playable over a decade later. If RTS games are your jam, this is a must. Edit: With more recent CPUs, multithreading might cause some issues with performance. Try disabling all but the first two cores for the game. In Windows, go to Task Manager, Details, Find the process and right click, Set Affinity, Then deselect all of the cores but Core 0 and 1. Besides setting compatibility mode, this has helped people out.

Though Empire at War isn’t the most complex or up-to-date RTS out there these days, it still holds a special place in many Star Wars fans' hearts for being one of the best video games made in the entire franchise. As someone who’s played this game nearly since release, I count myself among them! 

Gameplay wise it’s still a solid experience that certainly stands the test of time, with a unique grand strategy galactic conquest mode that much like Battlefront’s ground to space combat has yet to be replicated. Recently as well multiplayer has been restored back to the game and is fully playable, and is still a blast if you can get people together. With that this game is also host to a very active modding scene, both on Moddb and the Workshop, which has helped keep this game alive all these years, from simple reskins to total overhauls for both canon and legends material. Though I won’t lie and say there are no problems at all with this game; expect crashes, a lot of desync in multiplayer, and not so great AI - plus a lot of the overhaul mods can be confusing to fully grasp with their plethora of core gameplay changes, but it’s not all too terrible so long as you have patience. 

Now to the story! While that in the base game isn’t much to write home about, the DLC (Forces of Corruption) offers in my opinion one of the best Star Wars stories told yet, where you rebuild a once great criminal empire during the final hours of the Empire. It features a new way of play, and while the faction can be overpowered the expansion feels like a breath of fresh air in content and a plot that while connected to the overall story, decides to do something on its own. Sadly however, it seems that the game was almost forgotten about in the greater legends universe, and combined with the fact that there were no further expansions or sequel, the story started and ended here, which is even more of a shame given the cliffhanger ending [spoiler](and even more given its connections to KOTOR)[/spoiler]. 

Overall I would highly recommend grabbing this game, but on sale as $22 (CDN) is wayy too much for a game nearly two decades old. This is a must have for any Star Wars fan or RTS enthusiast!

The Jedi Order’s problem, among many, is Yoda. No being can wield that kind of power for centuries without becoming complacent at best or corrupt at worst. He has no idea that it’s overtaken him; he no longer sees all the little cumulative evils that the Republic tolerates and fosters, from slavery to endless wars, and he never asks, “Why are we not acting to stop this?” Live alongside corruption for too long, and you no longer notice the stench or choose to ignore it. The Jedi cannot help the slaves of Tatooine, but they can help the slave masters.

If you like Star Wars, and you like RTS, this is the game for you!

Advice:

3) Love it!

STAR WARS™ Empire at War is an absolute gem that continues to captivate fans and newcomers alike with its immersive gameplay and a dedicated community that has breathed new life into the game through incredible mods, even years after its initial release. This title not only delivers an exceptional strategy experience set in the Star Wars universe but also evokes a wave of nostalgia, transporting players back to cherished childhood memories.

Let's begin with the gameplay. Empire at War offers a strategic depth that is both engaging and satisfying. Whether you choose to command the forces of the Galactic Empire or lead the Rebel Alliance, you're presented with an array of strategic decisions to make. From managing resources and building fleets to deploying troops and engaging in tactical battles, every move counts as you strive for galactic dominance. The gameplay strikes a balance between accessibility and complexity, allowing players of varying skill levels to enjoy the experience while still offering enough depth to satisfy seasoned strategy enthusiasts.

One of the standout aspects of Empire at War is its incredible modding community. Even years after its release, the game continues to receive support from a passionate community that has created awe-inspiring mods. These mods range from complete overhauls that introduce new eras, factions, and gameplay mechanics, to small tweaks that enhance graphics and gameplay elements. The dedication and creativity of the modding community are truly remarkable, breathing new life into the game and providing endless replayability. The wealth of user-generated content ensures that there is always something fresh and exciting to explore, adding to the already rich Star Wars universe.

Furthermore, Empire at War invokes a strong sense of nostalgia that tugs at the heartstrings of players who experienced it as kids. The game's immersive Star Wars setting, iconic characters, and memorable battles create a wave of warm nostalgia, transporting players back to the excitement and wonder of their childhood. Reliving those cherished moments and rediscovering the game's mechanics and storyline is a truly special experience that reinforces the timeless appeal of Empire at War.

In conclusion, STAR WARS™ Empire at War is a strategic masterpiece that not only offers immersive gameplay set in the beloved Star Wars universe but also serves as a vessel for cherished childhood memories. The gameplay is engaging and rewarding, providing strategic depth and countless hours of galactic conquest. The enduring support from the modding community ensures a steady stream of fresh content and endless possibilities. Whether you're a fan of Star Wars or a strategy enthusiast, Empire at War delivers an experience that will leave you craving more. Revisiting this game is a nostalgic journey that allows you to relive the joy and wonder of playing it as a little kid, making it a truly unforgettable gaming experience.

My very first strategy game. It may be old but still good to have and play if people consider themselves Star wars nerds (Sorry if anyone gets offended reading this) but again star wars empire at war is a good star wars game I have so far.

I cannot believe how well this game has aged.. even today, time of writing (May 2023), this game can be a blast to play with on Windows 10 and all I had to do was install and play...  Even my "potato laptop" which somewhat struggles when playing Minecraft (Java edition) has little issues here.

[h1]Emerge yourself in the Star Wars galaxy![/h1]
Empire at War is an RTS based strategy game where your goal is to take control of either the Empire or the Rebel alliance in order to try and either dominate or free the universe. You can gain control over planets by placing your fleet in their orbit, followed by landing your troops in order to take full control.

If a planet is occupied or already under the control of your enemies then a battle will start: either in space or on the ground.

[b]It's RTS, but not as we know it ;)[/b]
When people mention RTS they often refer to [i]base building games[/i] that usually also involve resource gathering. Although 'Empire' also uses those game mechanics they don't apply during a fight: instead of relying on troop generation you instead rely on [i]reinforcements[/i] which you need to hold back at first in space because you can only have a certain amount of active units on the planet. If you can manage to occupy more so called reinforcement points then this unit cap will increase which will allow you to bring more forces into the fight. 
 
However, if you're on defense then the structures on the planet, like the barracks, will sporadically provide you with new units to command. 

In other words: there is a bit of base building involved, but that only happens outside of battles, then you'll need to decide what structures and troops to build.

[h1]The atmosphere is [i]mind blowing[/i], even today![/h1]
As one could expect from an RTS-type game your troops will say specific lines when you select them and/or give them orders. And to me it never gets old when I ask Darth Vader to use the force to destroy an incoming enemy ground vehicle and he tells me "All too easy...". 

But what I appreciate the most is that it gives you a much better impression of the real strength of both the Imperial and Alliance fleets alike. In the movies we get the impression that the Imperial fleet is Star Destroyers only and well.. they don't seem [i]that[/i] tough, do they?  So when you start playing as the Empire you may be a bit disappointed that: no star destroyers yet, but other ships which are also deadly themselves.

And then it happens: you unlock a higher tech tree and can now get a Star Destroyer and omg... you'll realize soon enough where it got that name from ;)  But at that same time you will probably also quickly learn to appreciate all the great achievements the Alliance manages to achieve with the little resources that they have available.

Then there's the story line.. here you follow the path of either the Empire or Alliance as it's plaid out between the original movies. And I [i]really[/i] enjoyed to experience the obvious tension that's building between Vader and Grand Moff Tarkin as the story goes on..   Tarkin almost mocking Vader for his pursue of some space pirates who "obviously pose no threat to the Empire" ;)

Of course.. you don't have to play things that way. You can also go for a total free for all where your only goal is to conquer or free the entire galaxy.

All in all I can highly recommend this title, even all the way in 2023. This is a classic.

As an added insult to EA for their recent debacle of Jedi: Survivor, I'm now writing a review for this absolute gem of an old game, which is only three years away from being 20 years old.

Not simply because it worked on launch (the norm for the time), not only because it's a Star Wars title, but because it is a Star Wars game that has maintained a dedicated playerbase for almost twenty years and still got a fairly recent update, all without any interference from "Electronic Arts" and their desire to ignore their flaws.

And this is why I say that if you want a good Star Wars game, you can't possibly go wrong with one from the mid two thousands, because the old Battlefronts are also still good.

By itself its a good game, editing the xml file to be cheaty and giving you more cash and pop cap to spam low rank weak ships to overwhelm the enemies superior and powerfull ships(ex: Corellion Gunboats and Corvette swarms vs Star Destroyers, even better. The workshop has a lot of mods/addons/DLCs that adds a lot of units and characters from the prequel trilogy and the EU (Ex: Thrawns Revenge, takes place after the battle of Endor. Republic at War, takes place during the Clone Wars. Admiral Trench from the Clone Wars with his modified Providence-class Carrier, General Grievous with bis flagship The Silent Hand etc.) Some revamps/overhaul/remakes that add in ships only talked about and seen in books and comics like the Pride of the Core, The Eclipse (Check out Eckartsladder's Battle of the Dreadnoughts on youtube to see what it would be capable of) as well as a few versions of the Super Star Destoyer like the Executor [Vaders Flagship seen in Return of the Jedi] The Dominance/Domination and more. Don't know if they added/made new mods for the Sequel trilogy but I don't want to touch those yet. Overall I recommend it for those who like managment games.

The Star Wars strategy game that you have been looking for.

Yes, this game is now pushing being 20 years old, but, its an oldie but goldie and embodies that very concept.

On its own, the game is not very good. The gameplay is dated, clunky and nothing spectacular. However, you do not buy this game for the base game itself. You buy this game and then install one or more mods. There are so many mods that completely change this game. They update the graphics, add new gameplay elements, new units, new stories, new models...the choice is quite frankly staggering.

So do yourself a favour, do without a cup of coffee or two for today and tomorrow and buy this. Its more than worth your time, effort and money.

I only bought the game because of mods, as the base game is archaic and very limited in terms of scope and features compared to more modern or robust RTS titles.
The modding scene however is honestly amesing and just for that it's worth to buy the game. You have graphical mods that update the game to 4k textures and beutifull ship remodels, you have complete overhauls that bring in tons of new ships and even factions into the game full of custom scenarios, and you even have mods that expand the campaign map to ridicoulus proportions!

This game is a must have for any Star Wars fan. It has a large universe for you to try to conquer. It can be repetitive but a really great game.

After many hours, I will give my honest opinion about this game.



The campaigns are alright. Skirmishes are amazing but get repetitive. Galactic Conquest is (imo) the best gamemode by far, as you command your own galactic power without constraints in terms of the galaxy's lore.

90% of this game is played through the mods. The vanilla experience + FOC is a great experience, and despite the graphics holds up alright today. You will however notice small bits of the game that stick out like they shouldn't be there like the fighter size and planets in the background being incredibly tiny due to the game's age.

However, these issues are fixed and remidied by the game's amazing mod community. There are so many mods that bring unique takes, renewed graphics and gameplay and a new perspective on the game which makes playing it over and over again worth it.

In my opinion, this game is 100% worth it from a modern day standpoint. I've sunk many hours into this game, and ill sink many more.

TLDR: Basegame is alright, experience is enhanced tremendously by the expansive mod community the game has. Great game that holds up to this day.

One of THE best RTS games in my personal opinion. mods for days and plently of tense moments on harder modes, Absolute 10/10... however. there is one issue that makes this game an F tier game in my opinion, and thats performance. you see kids, the game was designed back when CPUs in computers only had one or two cores at most, which is no big deal. they used what they had at the time. 

Its 2023

No regular computer CPU is like that anymore. 

Now yes they still do exist and heres a small bit of how it works. So the Core count of your CPU is what matters most, most nowdays are multicore, like 4+ cores. youd think the game runs better? no absolutely not. the game engine can really only use two at most and that because of how old the game is, and the tech they had at the time to work with. so if we say... idk that the old dual cores equal per core 10000 for example, and new cpus are 5000 per core. yes 2 x 10k and 4 X 5000 give 20K and both should be equally be capable of running the game, but if your computer can only harness 2 cores you really only get 10000 from that, and your left with half of what the computer is really needing to run the game smoothly. now that just a pisspoor example, its not accurate by any means, but thats how i can explain it and be able to sleep tonight. NOW there are some cpus that are designed to have stronger core ratings, so for those this game might run completely fine, but with a standard run of the mill Cpu that you bought for newer games? no nonono this game will crash and burn or just be frames per minute. its an amazing game and i love it so much but theres just so many issues that someone needs to go and remaster the game badly.

Gameplay and mechanics of all the mods, the love and the commitment to good gaming plus blowing up large star destroyers like a badass and conquering the galaxy? 20/10

the game running on my system? 0/10

He became so powerful… the only thing he was afraid of was losing his power, which eventually, of course, he did. I bought this game because I like Star Wars Rebellion and this is supposed to be its successor.: I completed the tutorial and the Empire campaign. Overall the game is good, although the fact that the units don't have stats but just an indication of what units they are strong or weak against is silly. Compared to Star Wars Rebellion, a much older RTS, it has less planets, no stats, less characters and character missions, less types of ships, no popular support mechanic...in short, it's more of a TACTICAL game than a strategy game. The resource economy and exploration and diplomacy mechanics are bare bones: the actual battle simulations take centre stage, and here both in Space and especially on the planets' surface EMPIRE AT WAR certainly surpasses its predecessor.

As this game is very old now the reason it is still so much fun is because of the follow workshop content that is also a requirement if you wanna get your moneys worth.  The 4 following mods are my favorites in no particular order.  Thrawns Revenge, Awakening of the Rebellion, The Fall of the Republic, and Empire At War Remake.

Each one of these mods are amazing and 2 of them Thrawns Revenge and Fall of the Republic are by the same mod author. If you want to see a tutorial for any of these mods check out the youtube channels: Corey Loses, TheXPGamer (Captain Shack), or Eckarharts Ladder. Between those 3 channels you should find at least one tutorial video for each mod.

Hidden gem of a space strategy game based on the Star Wars license. May not be for everyone but I liked it. I played through both campaigns but did not dive into the many mods you can try out, too.

Pros:
++ Star Wars license with a lot of vehicles and characters you will recognize
++ Space combat is fun and engaging
+ You can pause the game any time and give commands to your units (mostly, see cons)
++ Extending your territory and improving your planets and army is fun
+ Campaigns are interesting to play and try to follow the original movies plot, you might want to start with the empire one though as it is easier in my opinion

Cons:
-- Land based combat is not good, as your units / army is very limited in the beginning of every mission / planet map and the AI throws endless spawning units at you from the beginning if you are the attacker
- Unit path finding / behavior is not good
- You can pause in galaxy map mode but commanding units from A to B is not possible

Also this game has a lot of mods which extend it in many ways like the Clone Wars etc. They might be your thing, or not, have a look.
Space

The base game is definitely quite lackluster. (Give it the benefit of the doubt though - for a game from 2006 that hasn't received any content update, it's quite good.)

However, the mods for this game are insane. EAW remake and Thrawn's Revenge... (Chef's kiss)

If you like Star Wars, this game is for you. Even if you just like Grand Strategy (C'mon Hoi4 players), this game is for you. If you like a really good challenge, God above, you will love this.

However, if you are not the kind of guy whose idea of relaxing is sweating like crazy watching your incredibly expensive Super Star Destroyer get annihilated by pathetic little star-fighters because you did not build corvettes in time, then you probably should skip over this one.

But it's my favorite Star Wars Game... in the world. The mods are made better than most game devs could, the base game is respectable, and all the mods are free and could be considered sequels to this game.

And hey, if you buy this game, and if enough people do, they may make a sequel. If KOTOR gets one then this better get one.

I couldn't stop playing this game back when Windows XP was still supported even back then, this game was simply mindblowing on PC, an RTC on your favorite franchise... Man, those were the days.

When this game was brought into Steam, it was certainly an interesting choice, but it made modding tedious and for the most part, difficult to get mods like Republic At War to work around that period.

But sometime in 2015. Empire at War received one of the best updates most games back then would've never gotten. Multiplayer being completely re-patched, not needing Gamespy anymore, and making the game support the Steam Workshop.

This update alone has brought Empire at War out of its decaying state and became one of the most popular Lucasfilm games to mod, with mods like Thrawn's Revenge and Empire at War Remake, and many more that made Empire at War the amazing RTC game it is today.


If you're going to try this game out, be sure to experience it within the first 2 hours, then install a mod of your liking.

I will recommend anyone this game if they so desired.

Star Wars video games are known for space craft air-to-ground and air-to-air combat (Star Wars: Rogue Squadron [1998]) and Force users (KOTOR, Jedi: Fallen Order). Empire at War, though, is a different kind of creature! It is a strategy game. Therefore, one must THINK carefully before and after each move. Then, and only then, will one see the fruits of one's digital and mental labor!

Now, I'm not much of a strategy sort of player, but the devs had me at ''Star Wars: Empire at War''. Whether on sale or not, I highly recommend this game! 7.5/10 is what I rate the game!

This is a strategy game set in the star wars universe.
The best parts about it are the capabilities of having both land and space battles in a conquest mode.
Some units, especially in space have health points, which after being destroyed can weaken enemy or your own ships, which is an excellent concept also executed well. This makes larger ships suceptible to targeted attacks making units for any task needed, like fighter screening, bombers and even the basic heavy weaponry.
This with a simple currency system for building buildings and spaceships, increasing pop cap is just the main game. The sheer amount of creative ideas, although it's a relative old game, combined with simple elements makes it competable with the most modern of games.
The strength of this game comes truly to shine with the great modding support.

Star Wars: Empire at War, is a delightful game. Quick to learn, but with great replay ability. However, the thing that has kept this old game going better than anything else, is the mods and the modding community. This game is great for either a quick skirmish with friends or a longer grand campaign. 7/10.

Empire at War is a Chaotic Mess, lets go through the list of why I love it.
[list]
    [*] The campain mode is good, galactic conquest is far better.
    [*] Forces of corruption is a complete meme fest.
    [*] It comes with the gold pack for free.
    [*] Its very entertaining seeing everything fight and duke it out.
    [*] Factions are completely broken in their own ways. There isn't a reason behind this, they're all just absurd.
    [*] The Galaxy map looks good.
    [*] Space Battles look good.
    [*] Hero's have just as much plot armor as in the movies.
    [*] Voice Acting is all over the place, 10/10.
[/list]

Lets go over its [i]short comings[/i]
[list]
    [*] Balancing is a dead act.
    [*] There is no galactic conquest co-op mode.
[/list]

Played 3x FFA with friends. Destroyed one of my buddy's resource nodes, accidentally crippled him in the fight against our other buddy. To compensate, I destroyed my other buddy's resource node. First friend was so annoyed with me he negotiated a ceasefire and sicced the Empire on me, having a fleet of 5+ star destroyers constantly attacking my base while he destroyed my resource nodes. Slowly, I watched as my resources and ships vanished, except for Home One, which destroyed anything in its path. When only Home One remained, I limped it towards the Imperial Star Base so that it could go out in a blaze of glory fighting the Empire. Game crashed right as I arrived.
10/10 would play again.

one of the top 5 STARWARS games ever, and the modding scene is keeping this game alive and well for almost 20 years.

battles can be waged both on the ground and in space, you can build buildings that grant you additional units per planet and usually the AI is doing a decent job at putting up a fight.

theres also a campaign for the rebels and empire, that follows around the time of the construction till the death of the first deathstar and there are plenty of hero units that are tough to kill and can turn the tide of battles - and changin on where they are in the battle they can either be in a vehicle if its space battles or on the ground personally in ground battles

mods that i personally can recommend are:
THRAWNS REVENGE
REPUBLIC AT WAR
ABSOLUTE ENHANCMENT MOD\ABSOLUTE CHAOS MOD

also the game is easily modded, so if you find the unit limits a bit stifening, want to field more units in general or want to have more money, there are tutorials how the bypass and change these- just keep in mind that applies to you and the AI

overall an absolute must for any fan and anyone that loves strategy games

Gee, *glances at hours played* do I recommend it or not? That's a tough one.

(Even if you traditionally hate RTS, the base game is simple enough to get a handle on. Just DON'T rely on infantry to get the job done!)

The base game is good with all the necessary Star Wars and RTS stuff, with the big space battles and ground battles. But what brings this game from good to amazing is the modding community. They have kept this game running with amazing mods which update the graphics, add more factions, and also completely change the era of the game to the clone wars and many others. The modding community for this is one of the best I have ever seen and what they've been able to accomplish is a feat on its own.  But with that this game isn’t all that easy either when ramping up the difficulty whether you are playing a story driven campaign or choosing one of the factions to try and take over the galaxy. You’ll have to manage  your army and your planets to ensure victory. But really this is a Star Wars game so if you like Star Wars with their big battles and lightsabers or love RTS games I would recommend this game.

[h1]Introduction:[/h1]
Star Wars: Empire at War is a real-time strategy (RTS) game developed by Petroglyph Games and published by LucasArts. It was released in 2006 and is set in the Star Wars universe during the time of the Galactic Civil War. The game has gained a high status among RTS fans and is widely regarded as a must-play for fans of the genre.

[h1]Gameplay:[/h1]
In Empire at War, players can choose to control either the Rebel Alliance or the Galactic Empire in a campaign mode or in skirmishes against the AI or other players. The gameplay consists of building and managing bases, producing units and structures, and battling enemies on land and in space. The controls are responsive and intuitive, and the gameplay is fast-paced and enjoyable.

One unique feature of Empire at War is the ability to control space battles. Players can build and customize their own fleets, and then engage in epic space battles against enemy ships. This adds an extra layer of strategy and excitement to the game.

[h1]Story:[/h1]
The story of Empire at War follows the events of the Galactic Civil War, with players choosing to align with either the Rebel Alliance or the Galactic Empire. The story is told through cutscenes and missions, and is faithful to the Star Wars universe. The characters are well-developed and the pacing of the story is well-done, keeping the player engaged throughout the campaign.

[h1]Graphics and Sound:[/h1]
While the graphics of Empire at War are showing their age, they are still impressive for a game that is over 15 years old. The visual style is true to the Star Wars universe and the cutscenes are especially well-done. The sound design is also top-notch, with the music, sound effects, and voice acting all being excellent.

[h1]Replay Value:[/h1]
Empire at War has a high replay value thanks to its campaign mode and skirmish mode, as well as its multiplayer capabilities. There are also unlockable units and structures that can be unlocked through progression, which adds an extra layer of depth to the game.

In addition to the base game, the Forces of Corruption expansion pack adds even more replay value to Empire at War. The expansion adds a new campaign and a third faction, the Zenn Consortium, which allows for even more varied gameplay. It also adds new units, structures, and features, making it feel like almost an entirely new game in and of itself.

[h1]Conclusion:[/h1]
Overall, Star Wars: Empire at War is an excellent RTS game that is a must-play for fans of the genre. Its campaign mode, skirmish mode, and multiplayer capabilities give it a high replay value, and the Forces of Corruption expansion pack adds even more content and depth to the game. The sound design is top-notch, and the story is faithful to the Star Wars universe. While the graphics may be showing their age, they are still impressive for a game that is over 15 years old. Overall, Empire at War is a game that any RTS fan should check out.

This game scratches an itch where you just want to hop in and experience the universe from a birds eye view. A fun pass time is just putting the game on the easiest difficulty and building an overwhelming army in Galactic Conquest, then using it to roam the galaxy annihilating the rebels or empire. The music is all appropriate from the movies, the characters are voiced great, and hidden beneath the fan service is an actually pretty functional RTS. 

You even get it in two flavors, space and ground battles. The resource management is pretty simplistic though so don't expect to see anything like building actual functioning bases and moving out like in Age of Empires or Starcraft, more so a squad based arena type battle for each.

Star Wars: Empire at War is quite possibly the finest RTS I've had the pleasure of playing, everything from the economic systems and acquiring of resources to the breakneck strategic combat, this shits good.
I highly recommend the thing.

The gameplay is top tier as I've stated, although the Campaigns in Base-Game aren't anything revolutionary in terms of Star Wars stories, but Forces of Corruption shakes it up a bit with the Corruption Mechanics and all the criminal underworld shit. Jabba be damned!

The campaigns are well and good but at the heart of it is Galactic Conquest, where you fight for control of the system and work towards a goal, like stopping the Empire or Building the Deathstar, buuut ummm I usually just play skirmishes so I'm not exactly an expert on it, however that brings me to my favorite part:

Skirmishes!
Skirmishes are essentially isolated single battles you can play against AI or your friends if ya got sum. Its all very tight gameplay wise but certain maps are better than others and I find space battles more enjoyable than land battles generally.

AllinAll, Empire at War is tight as hell, If you like Star Wars, give it a try!

vanilla is great for smaller scale space battles but some of the mods really take this game from in my opinion a 8/10 to a masterpiece, the games ground battles arent it's strong suit and I don't really enjoy them but the space battles are cinematic and very strategic while not being as basic as the rock paper scissors type ground battles. If you were thinking about picking this game up do it and especially while it's on sale.

Honestly, I have no idea how this game has 97% positive reviews.

Campaign- in between missions, you are able to build whatever units you like and invade some other planets, so there's no challenge.

On the ground level, you generally need all your troops to be together so they don't get crushed, and there's a variety of enemy types, so your only response is to have one of each soldier type, so there's not really any strategy there. There's also no terrain, so really all you do is send your stack of units towards the enemy, and there's not much strategy involved. Some of the unit abilities are neat, but not enough to carry the game.

written by AI, but I agree: I recently played Star Wars: Empire at War: Force of Corruption and was blown away by the immersive gameplay and engaging storyline. As a huge fan of the Star Wars franchise, I was thrilled to be able to experience the story of the Empire and the Rebel Alliance from a different perspective, as the leader of a criminal organization known as the Zann Consortium.

One of the things I loved most about this game was the depth of strategy and planning that was required to succeed. The game features a robust and complex gameplay system that allows players to manage their resources, build their armies, and plan their attacks in order to conquer their enemies and expand their territory.

The graphics and visuals in the game are stunning, and the attention to detail is impressive. The game's environments and characters are incredibly realistic, and the cutscenes and voice acting are top-notch. I was thoroughly engrossed in the game's story and found myself completely invested in the lives and struggles of the characters.

In conclusion, I highly recommend Star Wars: Empire at War: Force of Corruption to any fans of the Star Wars franchise or strategy games. The game offers hours of engaging gameplay and a thrilling story that will keep players coming back for more. I can't wait to see what the future holds for the Zann Consortium and the Star Wars universe.

Disney's management of Star Wars is questionable (they are garbage imo, or rather EA is garbage since we are talking about games here), but I respect the revival of BFII and EaW multiplayer a lot. If you didn't know, they released a update to fix the broken multiplayer function caused by Gamespy closing about a year ago. A wonderful thing, and they added Steam Workshop which allows easy access to mods which this game is not short of. Previously Moddb was the main site for mods and still is very active. Due to this revival I do have -one small amount of respect for Disney, and I hold Petroyglyph in high regard and sincerely hope they get to make a new "EaW II" some day which they have showed interest in.

The game
A extremely fun SW RTS game with no equal. The graphics may not be up to today's standards but the gameplay is as good as ever. Fight battles on land and space. Either in small single-game skirmishes, or in the Galactic Conquest where you fight over the entire (or a part) of the Galaxy with or without other objectives and goals. The game also comes with 3 campaigns: Empire, Rebels and Connsortium. The third only being in FoC, so you can't start the Empire or Rebel compaign in FoC. Likewise you cant start the Connsortium campaign in EaW.  

The units are fun and you can find most of the vehicles and troops found in the original trilogy with other fun additions for a even larger amount of variety, balance and enjoyment. Rebel/Stormtrooper infantry, AT-ATs, AT-STs, Speeders, Hoovercraft, Snow Speeders and of course Hero units. Equiped with unique abilities, enhanced weapons or even lightsabers and the force. How, or if to use these is entirely up to you.

There are 5 major mods that most people will play, those 5 being;
1. Thrawn's Revenge (Post-Endor, Pre-Disney fucking up the EU)
2. Republic at War (Clone Wars)
3. Fall of the Republic (A replacement for RaW ~kinda)
4. Empire at War Remake (Think Thrawn's Revenge but movies 4, 5, 6 with a heavy focus on visuals and graphics)
5. Awakening of the Rebellion (For the people who play the wrong faction)

if you plan on playing a modded Galactic conquest, give up.
If you plan on playing a modded skirmish (or non-modded even), have a good internet connection, and stick to space. Do not play land-control.

Play like a turtle and win. Auto-resolve is not your friend, and mapping WASD back to movement is probably for the best. 
Having the DLC is mandatory, as most mods need it and it allows for auto-casting of abilities.

When using mods, make sure to use the code in properties such as "STEAMMOD=1770851727" and etc.
This game will always be a classic

The campaigns are light on lore but decently challenging on higher difficulties; the Forces of Corruption campaign is peak Legends writing in many ways, and the game is a blast to play. The campaigns of the base game offer certain tidbits of lore (for example, how the Alliance brought X-wings into their fleets) and the characterization is handled well (Tarkin is appropriately menacing, noting that if half of a force of captured Wookiee slaves is wiped out, "the survivors will work twice as hard") but the overall plot is pretty barebones. Galactic Battlegrounds did that part better, although this game was somewhat hindered by the larger scope in that regard. The original music for this game complements the Williams tracks well, and is composed by Frank Klepacki, a legend in the industry whose contributions include the scores of Red Alert 2 and the weird (and underappreciated) Blade Runner game.

In conclusion; the game itself is amazing, but the mods are what makes is perfect.

A truly incredible strategy game.

I remember watching YouTube videos of its vanilla campaign when I was 10-12, and finally started playing in 2019. The modding community is EXCELLENT, especially Corey's team who make Thrawn's Revenge and its spinoffs.

I have played dozens of hours with almost all of the factions in Thrawn's Revenge, and it keeps bringing me back. Can't wait for 3.3!

The base gameplay is fun but the restrictions on the base game when compared to the mods that are possible with the Forces of Corruption DLC make it harder to enjoy when the alternatives are just one click away.

I highly recommend this game to any Star Wars fan (plenty of juicy Legends content in many of the best mods!) and to anyone who enjoys RTS combat that's not heavy on micromanagement. The galactic layer is incredible, and the large-scale conquest and war on multiple fronts styles of gameplay is endlessly engaging.

EAW Is one of the best  Star Wars RTS's I have ever played. The base game quite good, diving into lore on the Empire and Rebellion before the battle of Yavin and creation of the death star. But where the game really shines is in the modding community. Playing with mods makes the game so much more enjoyable. I have spent so much time just going through mods on the workshop and finding mods I never knew existed. Some Change the Era from the Galactic Civil War to the Clone Wars (such as Fall of the Republic). Others Just revamp the base game adding more units, Heroes, and mechanics (like the EAW Remake 4.0). If you are looking into this game and you are interested in Star Wars and RTS's, i would for sure,  say you buy EAW. Again the base game is good, but consider digging through the Steam Workshop and finding a Mod that hooks your interest. If you don't know what mods to play, I would personally recommend Awakening of The Rebellion, Fall of the Republic, EAW Remake 4.0, and Thrawns Revenge.

An immensely satisfying RTS at a base level with space AND land battles that both have their own flavor, and unique mechanics like the overworld galactic conquest and theater cam that make even the original base game a timeless classic and really help make the game feel like you're overseeing the world of Star Wars. Add on to that the DLC which heavily expanded and updated on the game to make it even more mechanically interesting and replayable. Then take into account the countless hours of work put in by the game's lovely modding community to enhance that complexity even further, and you have one of the best Star Wars games, AND best RTS games ever developed. Excellent in 2006 and excellent in 2022, this game in my opinion is truly a timeless classic. I love it with all my heart.

Played this game when it first came out. Bought it out of Nostalgia. OMG, forgot how much fun it is. The Regular setting is challenging, especially if you are playing campaign and want to get all the planets in both factions. The expansion "Corruption" has a couple of learning mechanics, but it is still enjoyable.

Short answer: Yes

Public service announcement: If you find that the game suddenly doesn't launch from Steam anymore, closing after a second or two without any warnings or error messages whatsoever, try setting all six executables to compatibility mode for WinXP SP3 and Run as Admin. These are the StarWarsG.exes, the sweaw and swfoc.exes and the runme/runme2.exes in the root folder. Then make sure that the Steam.exe is Run as Admin as well - it will complain about being in compatibility mode but ignore it. I don't know how or why the game spontaneously stopped working - I had un/reinstalled everything, including C++ redists, cleared the registry, you name it. Only the above got it to work.

The space battles are very nice, the ground battles less so. This game kind of takes number 1 spot as "best star wars RTS" but to be honest, nothing better has come along. It's a fun 'light' 4x strategy game with lots of unit variety and nods to the old expanded universe, but the feel of the units and camera is very 'floaty' and unresponsive. There's mods too but most of them are like "wow what if we put the lore number of turbolasers on everything, wow that really lowered the FPS". It's a good game, not great, just good. Frank Klepacki did the music but it's not really his best work.

A very interesting take on the RTS genre. It's sort of like a mix between Halo Wars and League of Legends. Empire at War and its expansion, Forces of Corruption are both a mixture of 2 older Star Wars games: Rebellion and Galactic Battlegrounds Saga. They take the pure RTS components of Galactic Battlegrounds Saga and mix it with the more conquest/control aspects of Rebellion. Play as either the rebels/empire, or pirates in the expansion. Great story and lore buried in this game.

The game is decent, even for its age, but it is riddled with bugs.
- Autosave just doesn't happen at all.  So when something glitches and you need to reload you better pray you just manually saved.
- Objective is frequently confusing.
- Campaigns just abruptly end.  There really is no "need" to capture planets when you can just follow the story planets.
- Constant little bugs and issues, especially with pathing and grouping.

I don't REGRET buying it, but I also wouldn't recommend it.

the games a worth while buy, even though its age will show at times primarily with the planetary invasions the game play is truly something unique. The games scope is pretty large with the galactic conquest mode, and its skirmish mode can just take you straight into the combat if you don't want to sink in the time for galactic conquest. By far one of the best features is the cinematic camera that the game has built into it, the camera does a pretty good shot of showing you the action of large scale and small scale battles almost as if you where watching it in theaters.

It should go without say that some degree of skill is required for this game, while its not necessary it can give you an edge in a battle even though a fleet of star destroyers could thrash most things thrown at it a good use of star fighters can really cripple said star destroyer fleet. The game does a good job at balancing there's enough ship variety in each faction where simply spamming one ship wont win you the game, on top of that star fighters while small do make a difference in battle having bombers and your enemy being unable to defend against them can really turn around a battle by hitting key sections of a ship such as the engines, hanger and shield generator.

over all this game is really worth it, especially on sale if the original trilogy isn't completely your thing the game has an active mod community which can overhaul the game, set you other parts of the timeline, or just make the game look newer.

Despite its age, Empire at War is an awesome strategy game that I love picking up again and again when I'm itching for some old fashioned Star Wars combat. I grew up with the original IV, V and VI films, so those are the ship designs I fell in love with.

Empire at War still has a very dedicated modding community, so there's a lot of really cool update mods that make for new experiences and improve upon the gameplay. The mods are what keep me coming back frankly, but I still love the game for what it is.

Tip: To launch the forces of corruption expansion, open the game from your steam library, then when the game asks if you want to play empire at war: gold pack, or forces of corruption, select forces of corruption. The only reason you would need or want to play the normal version is if you want to play the rebellion or empire campaign, as they are not in forces of corruption, being replaced by the consortium campaign, otherwise, forces of corruption is far better in every other aspect as a third faction adds more complexity and fun to multiplayer and singleplayer galactic conquest and skirmish.

This game is as old as it is and still has a place as one of my favourite games. I love the different game modes that can be played and the community that is still prevalent after 17 years. The modding community have produced so many great mods that revitalise the game and some of my favourite mods to name a few (EAW, TR, RAW, AOTR) have made the game fun to play. The multiplayer games are always fun to play and require little skill as I have seen some of the best players I know lose to some hit-and-run rebel tactics or even the neglect of fighter support. For those Star Wars fans I 100% Recommend it and hope you enjoy it too.

This game, you want to like it. I know! I'm right there with ya, but it just isn't there. The A.I cheats to a shocking degree. I had my suspicions when the rebels were consistently losing but still had 15 capital ships to throw at me, but when I played the conquest mode on medium and had Chewbacca and Han Solo, plus another Chewbacca and Han Solo, in their attack force, well, that just put a sour taste in my mouth.

The campaign is disgusting in that it pretends to involve choice and strategy but, in the very first mission I tried to play and the enemy is pulling whole armies out of its backside whenever I complete objectives...yeah, no. We aren't doing this, darling.

Finally, just trying to play the game I encounter weird issues in gameplay, with my forces not following my commands, control groups overwriting each other without my input and even going so far as to have the mouse cursor disappear. Not become invisible, outright disappear, forcing me to go to enter and leave the escape menu to resume commanding my forces in this so-called strategy game.

As for mods...I'm just saying here, if they are why you play this game, that's fine...but it isn't the developer's work that made it happen. Some guys, in their spare time, are doing a better job than the developers. That's problematic...

I know, everyone. Star Wars just begs to have a good RTS made out of it, but this isn't it. Avoid it, ignore it, shun it, even put it out of its misery and bury it in a pinewood box out in the desert, but absolutely do not pay money for it.

I would almost not recommend this, but it is an old game and if you're real into star wars, then you should get it. I want to like it, it tries to do something very cool with a galaxy conquest thing, but unfortunately it makes no sense to actually play the maps in most cases if you wan to efficiently win a campaign. 

Just auto battle everything with the largest stack of units you can make and then remake units and keep auto battling. You could elect to actually manually play the battles, but it would take much longer and even if you get a better kill ratio it doesn't matter, just spam more units. 

Imagine you play an RPG with many tiers of equipment, but at the start there are weapons that will one hit kill anything in the game and you can buy them in any shop. You could say "just don't use them", but then you have to pretend play, you are no longer constrained to play a certain way and the challenge of the game feels stupid.

A very creative game. It is always good to see parts of the Star Wars galaxy that did not appear in the movies, created so vividly like this. The planets and their unique weather and inhabitants create an impression of a vast galaxy that it very difficult to get bored with, and the style the game uses to portray space combat is something I had never seen anything like - an absolute must for any RTS gamer. I originally did not recommend this game because of difficulty trying to progress through the Rebel campaign on medium (the Imperial Fleet is very strong and persistent about where it wants to attack). I later managed to beat the Rebel campaign by winning at the strategic level rather than obsessing over specific results of battles (you can pick which planets to launch offensives on), capturing where the enemy is weak rather than meeting them directly, and trying to cut the Empire's fleets off from reinforcement along hyperspace routes. This way, the Empire's powerful fleets are allowed to win their battles, but they are not decisive victories, and eventually the Rebels can return to finish these fleets off after securing more resources and forces. The Imperial campaign was very easy and there didn't seem to be much to it; their forces are just more durable and just positioning a small fleet in a good formation seems to usually result in the Rebels all dying, provided the enemy hangar is also sniped by missile cruisers to deny them reinforcements. I never figured out the planet-based ion cannon option for the Rebels to stun enemy ships and only noticed they could do this when I was playing as the Empire, so this may be part of why I struggled as the Rebels.
FOR THE SEPARATIST ALLIANCE

star wars

GOD YES THIS GAME IS GREAT! First, while it may look old and maybe even boring, this game is a joy to play with the large modding community. Second, I would recommend that you play the base game first so you get a hang of it before trying mods. The mods are what make the game so interesting in today's modern "great graphics" society. Finally, one warning before you get it, its going to be hard at first. When I first started it felt almost like a waste of money because there will be times where you go "damn, this is kinda hard". I mean, it is a strategy game. Then when you realize that your fighting a 16 year-old AI, you feel dumb. That's why they have skirmish. You have to use. learn what combinations work and which don't. how to overpower capital ships with small ships. Its a part of the game that you need in order to progress. Overall, great purchase and would recommend to any fan of space, star wars, and strategy games.
